Change openstack-dev to openstack-discuss

Mailinglists have been updated. Openstack-discuss replaces
openstack-dev.

subject: Update master for stable/stein
messages: [{'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2019-04-03 15:12:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-22 16:41:52.000000000', 'message': 'Update master for stable/stein

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/stein.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/stein.

Change-Id: I95a36e6974a0b25742331b820d869e1be90e9c44
Sem-Ver: feature
'}]
commit_message:
Update master for stable/stein

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/stein.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/stein.

Change-Id: I95a36e6974a0b25742331b820d869e1be90e9c44
Sem-Ver: feature

[{'created': '2019-03-28 06:20:47.000000000', 'message': "Display first volume image_metadata as an instance image

When instance is created from cinder volume, it's image is not displayed
Nowdays using cinder as instance source becomes more widespread,
so there is sense in displaying instance image,
when instance is created from cinder volumes.
We're trying to get volume_image_metadata from the first volume of
the instance, when instance doesn't have image attribute itself.
First volume is suggested based on its device name (eg. '/dev/vda').

This info is displayed only in instances list, not in detail overview.

Change-Id: I00aa9ef07d1680bb2390a30271bb39cd7bea6329
(cherry picked from commit 3c82a38f71d52e7a59812c3f2d9f89fe066258f3)
"}]
commit_message:
Display first volume image_metadata as an instance image

When instance is created from cinder volume, it's image is not displayed
Nowdays using cinder as instance source becomes more widespread,
so there is sense in displaying instance image,
when instance is created from cinder volumes.
We're trying to get volume_image_metadata from the first volume of
the instance, when instance doesn't have image attribute itself.
First volume is suggested based on its device name (eg. '/dev/vda').

This info is displayed only in instances list, not in detail overview.

Change-Id: I00aa9ef07d1680bb2390a30271bb39cd7bea6329
(cherry picked from commit 3c82a38f71d52e7a59812c3f2d9f89fe066258f3)

subject: Not implicitly set vol_device_name to vda
messages: [{'account_id': 20944, 'date': '2019-04-01 13:39:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-04-02 14:51:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-04-03 15:32:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nThis is a thing nice to have, but it is not release critical.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-04-03 15:52:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-01 13:39:33.000000000', 'message': "Not implicitly set vol_device_name to vda

Using a scsi decorated image with:
hw_disk_bus='scsi'
hw_scsi_model='virtio-scsi'

This solve the case where an instance is
launched with 'image' selected as boot
source with a new volume. This will result
in /dev/vda instead of /dev/sda as it
should.

Not specifying device name in
setFinalSpecBootImageToVolume() leaves the
decision to nova to determine it.

Example:
-------
VM boot volume without scsi meta data decoration:
Attached To
0a0cd660-7ce3-4033-9983-2e1099edc5f0 on /dev/vda

VM boot volume with scsi meta data decoration:
Attached To
91f50dbc-8bdf-4293-84ea-fc5df27b5ee4 on /dev/sda
--------

Note: This commit doesn't address cases for
where instances are launched using existing
volume and snapshot, this will involve more
work to migrate the code from BDMv1 to BDMv2.

Closes-Bug #1560965

Change-Id: I9d114c2c2e6736a8f1a8092afa568f930b656f09
(cherry picked from commit 4788c4d2f59b8aa08e5f599a6d2c327b6004dc0c)
"}]
commit_message:
Not implicitly set vol_device_name to vda

Using a scsi decorated image with:
hw_disk_bus='scsi'
hw_scsi_model='virtio-scsi'

This solve the case where an instance is
launched with 'image' selected as boot
source with a new volume. This will result
in /dev/vda instead of /dev/sda as it
should.

Not specifying device name in
setFinalSpecBootImageToVolume() leaves the
decision to nova to determine it.

Example:
-------
VM boot volume without scsi meta data decoration:
Attached To
0a0cd660-7ce3-4033-9983-2e1099edc5f0 on /dev/vda

VM boot volume with scsi meta data decoration:
Attached To
91f50dbc-8bdf-4293-84ea-fc5df27b5ee4 on /dev/sda
--------

Note: This commit doesn't address cases for
where instances are launched using existing
volume and snapshot, this will involve more
work to migrate the code from BDMv1 to BDMv2.

Closes-Bug #1560965

Change-Id: I9d114c2c2e6736a8f1a8092afa568f930b656f09
(cherry picked from commit 4788c4d2f59b8aa08e5f599a6d2c327b6004dc0c)

commit_message:
Update master for stable/stein

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/stein.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/stein.

Change-Id: I54c470e49d0def63e8d5a770efbdf98cce14489b
Sem-Ver: feature

Let me figure out how the private key arguments propagate to the ceph-ansible invocation'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-03-27 20:46:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-03-27 21:09:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Summarizing IRC discussion regarding this:

- Patch was applied with Michele's http://paste.openstack.org/show/748506 (seems correct)
- CI ceph jobs use standalone deployment so mistral/ceph integration wasn't exercised
- When I tested with an undercloud/overcloud deployment I hit http://paste.openstack.org/show/748497/
- With this change, ceph-ansible is invoked on container host (undercloud) and not in mistral container
- "To invoke on the host, ansible makes an ssh connection to the undercloud using that new private key"
- "Possibly that key is being used for the subsequent ceph-ansible invocation, which is wrong"
- Perhaps this patch can be updated to handle correct key use for ceph-ansible'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2019-03-27 21:44:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2019-04-02 02:57:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1 -Workflow

The updates job is failing because the package_update workflow is invoked with an inventory that is missing the tripleo-admin undercloud private key.

The code path for generating this inventory is a bit tortured:
- tripleoclient.utils.get_tripleo_ansible_inventory executes /usr/bin/tripleo-ansible-inventory (which is packaged in tripleo-validations!!)
- /usr/bin/tripleo-ansible-inventory builds the inventory with tripleo-common.inventory.TripleoInventory

This will take a bit to untangle, my first thought is that the workflow should be generating its own inventory, or the existing /var/lib/mistral/overcloud/tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml should be used'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2019-04-02 21:17:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2019-04-02 22:16:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-04-02 22:38:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2019-04-02 22:39:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Set the private key for undercloud tripleo-admin

This means the access workflow no longer needs to inject the public
key into the undercloud authorized_keys file, since there is already a
key configured and ready to use.

Change-Id: I4c6d0b87f4436713ba7080175308ed715907c111
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/649460/

'}]
commit_message:
systemd: reduce verbosity when removing a container

If a container that isn't suppose to be managed by systemd and is
removed, we used to send a warning saying that no systemd unit file was
found for this container.

Warning is too much, let's just use "info" level for that message.

Change-Id: I1c4de6e9d1347a20053cb33aea5c3cff20ab979a

commit_message:
Add support for generating form-post signatures

swift has the capability of allowing limited access to upload objects
via a pre-generated signature:

  https://docs.openstack.org/swift/latest/api/form_post_middleware.html

Add methods to support setting keys as well as generating the timestamp
and signature needed to use this.

Change-Id: Iab2fb5c225d0c8e79a16130f2352de1efd6cad4b

commit_message:
Update master for stable/stein

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/stein.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/stein.

Change-Id: I19a4d51260a689167bfe3de8bd28c0ac644aa62d
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.
Update to reflect reality, which should help with local running of
constraints targets.

Change-Id: Ic6e6b6922309829c7a311bc255a269bd8a458fb7

commit_message:
Add an Endpoint in ceilometer

Added an endpoint in the ceilometer configuration
to dispatch the data to qdr running locally.

Depends-On: Ib3090c01bfdcb60168dd1c6db23c520a103c051e
Change-Id: I7bbac48f2dfa9ec532f56a814af25117e11511ea

subject: Add unittest tree structure check
messages: [{'account_id': 8655, 'date': '2019-04-03 10:32:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2019-04-03 12:41:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nThanks Kuba!! Great stuff'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2019-04-03 13:12:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-03 10:32:55.000000000', 'message': 'Add unittest tree structure check

The patch adds a script taken from Neutron tree that checks the unittest
tree structure. The patch also fixes wrong files and moves the code to
proper place.

Change-Id: I475692f73523a317fdeb7406bcc68b98e555c3f9
Signed-off-by: Jakub Libosvar <libosvar@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add unittest tree structure check

The patch adds a script taken from Neutron tree that checks the unittest
tree structure. The patch also fixes wrong files and moves the code to
proper place.

Change-Id: I475692f73523a317fdeb7406bcc68b98e555c3f9
Signed-off-by: Jakub Libosvar <libosvar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Make tripleo-build-containers-centos-7 voting

Assures that the job is triggered when relevant files are touched.

Defines file patterns which could have allowed breaking changes
to go in untested, the implicit ones from parent not being enough.

Change-Id: I5aa4eb466f2369740cd66d087c71c36d44ff7623

subject: [WIP/DNM] This adds the lcm.sh script for lifecylce management
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-01 18:27:42.000000000', 'message': '[WIP/DNM] This adds the lcm.sh script for lifecylce management

Note to reviewers: This commit is a POC, and will not be able to pass
the gates without changing the gates

Problems this commit addresses:

* We want to introduce usage of Argo Workflows to our current process, which
  uses Helm. This doesn't work too well, because a Workflow is a sort of "one
  and done" deal. Once the Helm chart has been installed, there's virtually no
  way to change it, since everything was done by the Workflow, and the Workflow
  can't be rerun
* There's a semantics issue with `helm install` - It makes sense to /deploy/ a
  service, but for upgrading/deleting/backing-up/etc, it's a bit nonsense.

A solution:

* Helm install installs an armada-like object into the cluster.  This object
  knows things like where the chart is located.  It might also be beneficial to
  include configmaps in this object.

* We then supply a handful of Argo Workflows, where each wf is associated with
  a lifecycle event for the chart. We might have these wfs:
  - Install
  - Backup
  - Upgrade
  - Delete
  This solves the issue of including an Argo Workflow into a helm chart

* Finally, we create a lifecycle management tool (lcm.sh in this POC),
  which wraps helm template and kubectl apply to instantiate Workflows.
  The Lifecycle then looks something like this:

  ```
  # Inject the relevant configmaps, secrets, etc into the cluster
  helm install keystone ./keystone --namespace=openstack
  # Instantiate the install workflow
  ./lcm.sh install keystone
  # Make some changes to upgrade the keystone chart,
  # and instantiate the upgrade workflow
  ./lcm.sh install upgrade

Future:
* This process may be streamlined - this needs some experimentation, but it may
  be possible to create generic workflows which work for any given Openstack
  service. That is, rather than having multiple `lifecycle-events` directories,
  we create a single directory which is then shared among all services

Change-Id: I1aa58e077af06e5467488ec195a89813b32229c4

commit_message:
[WIP/DNM] This adds the lcm.sh script for lifecylce management

Note to reviewers: This commit is a POC, and will not be able to pass
the gates without changing the gates

Problems this commit addresses:

* We want to introduce usage of Argo Workflows to our current process, which
  uses Helm. This doesn't work too well, because a Workflow is a sort of "one
  and done" deal. Once the Helm chart has been installed, there's virtually no
  way to change it, since everything was done by the Workflow, and the Workflow
  can't be rerun
* There's a semantics issue with `helm install` - It makes sense to /deploy/ a
  service, but for upgrading/deleting/backing-up/etc, it's a bit nonsense.

A solution:

* Helm install installs an armada-like object into the cluster.  This object
  knows things like where the chart is located.  It might also be beneficial to
  include configmaps in this object.

* We then supply a handful of Argo Workflows, where each wf is associated with
  a lifecycle event for the chart. We might have these wfs:
  - Install
  - Backup
  - Upgrade
  - Delete
  This solves the issue of including an Argo Workflow into a helm chart

* Finally, we create a lifecycle management tool (lcm.sh in this POC),
  which wraps helm template and kubectl apply to instantiate Workflows.
  The Lifecycle then looks something like this:

  ```
  # Inject the relevant configmaps, secrets, etc into the cluster
  helm install keystone ./keystone --namespace=openstack
  # Instantiate the install workflow
  ./lcm.sh install keystone
  # Make some changes to upgrade the keystone chart,
  # and instantiate the upgrade workflow
  ./lcm.sh install upgrade

Future:
* This process may be streamlined - this needs some experimentation, but it may
  be possible to create generic workflows which work for any given Openstack
  service. That is, rather than having multiple `lifecycle-events` directories,
  we create a single directory which is then shared among all services

Change-Id: I1aa58e077af06e5467488ec195a89813b32229c4

commit_message:
Refactor passing libvirt environment variables

Fixes problems caused by passing of empty environment variables
related to libvirt.

New implementation avoids this and also allows users of the role
to define new default values or to change the passenv values.

Change-Id: Icb27a688c3dbe6eba77254db2e21a041234fe606

subject: WIP: Avoid overriding system python packages on diskimage_builder
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4162, 'name': 'Paul Belanger', 'email': 'pabelanger@redhat.com', 'username': 'pabelanger'}, {'_account_id': 8175, 'name': 'Rafael Folco', 'email': 'rfolco@redhat.com', 'username': 'rfolco'}, {'_account_id': 10118, 'name': 'IBM PowerKVM CI', 'email': 'kvmpower@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'powerkvm', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24162, 'name': 'Sorin Sbârnea', 'display_name': 'zbr', 'email': 'ssbarnea@redhat.com', 'username': 'ssbarnea', 'status': 'do not feed the troll 🥕'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-13 12:21:16.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Avoid overriding system python packages on diskimage_builder

Change behavior of diskimage_builder so it would install and use
the operating system python (pip/setuptools/virtualenv) and install
newer versions using --user.

This makes newer versions available to root user without conflicting
with system packages.

The previous yum/dnf exclude approach did not work well as it would
break packages that do list one of the excluded files as dependencies,
preventing them from being installed or updated, as they could require
a newer version of these packages.

The entire altering of basic operating system to inject newer packages
works againt testing policy where we need to test compatibility of our
code with a specific operating system. If we test it with somethign
that is no longer a supported version of the operating system, the
result of the testing is not to be valid anymore as is likely that
it will miss to spot bugs that would be faced by the customer.

It is ok to install newer packages as long they are not installed in
the same location as system packages. That's where pip `--user` comes
handy, the only downside is that it needs to be done for each user that
would want to benefit from it. Arguably the build jobs can take care of
this themselves as this does not require root access.

Change-Id: Ie9a1002c0bcdfec56a236e348d064cd560669313
Related-Bug: #1808118
"}]
commit_message:
WIP: Avoid overriding system python packages on diskimage_builder

Change behavior of diskimage_builder so it would install and use
the operating system python (pip/setuptools/virtualenv) and install
newer versions using --user.

This makes newer versions available to root user without conflicting
with system packages.

The previous yum/dnf exclude approach did not work well as it would
break packages that do list one of the excluded files as dependencies,
preventing them from being installed or updated, as they could require
a newer version of these packages.

The entire altering of basic operating system to inject newer packages
works againt testing policy where we need to test compatibility of our
code with a specific operating system. If we test it with somethign
that is no longer a supported version of the operating system, the
result of the testing is not to be valid anymore as is likely that
it will miss to spot bugs that would be faced by the customer.

It is ok to install newer packages as long they are not installed in
the same location as system packages. That's where pip `--user` comes
handy, the only downside is that it needs to be done for each user that
would want to benefit from it. Arguably the build jobs can take care of
this themselves as this does not require root access.

Change-Id: Ie9a1002c0bcdfec56a236e348d064cd560669313
Related-Bug: #1808118

Glance tests are currently too verbose for subunit and make
them randomly fail under python 3.

Using six.assertRaisesRegex() should get rid of the

Change-Id: I3297757b640bba9204243d2816bb3eb3aea0e4b4

commit_message:
Quiesce assertRaisesRegexp deprecation messages

Glance tests are currently too verbose for subunit and make
them randomly fail under python 3.

Using six.assertRaisesRegex() should get rid of the
"PendingDeprecationWarning: Please use assertRaisesRegex instead"
messages.

[{'created': '2019-01-11 16:06:35.000000000', 'message': 'Workaround for random virtualenv recreation failure

Recreating a virtualenv can fix some of its problems but there are
cases where nothign can be done. One such example is when there
is a lingering python process that is using this virtualenv.

We may not be able to kill the proces (or not a good idea) so better
we display an unique message, list python processes, move the folder
and recreate a clean virtualenv.

This should prevent a failure while still getting traceable information
regarding when it occurs.

Change-Id: Idfa4980215cb5489aa94c4ee7e55cdd160ed77d6

commit_message:
Workaround for random virtualenv recreation failure

Recreating a virtualenv can fix some of its problems but there are
cases where nothign can be done. One such example is when there is a
lingering python process that is using this virtualenv.

We may not be able to kill the proces (or not a good idea) so better
we display an unique message, list python processes, move the folder
and recreate a clean virtualenv. This should prevent a failure while
still getting traceable information regarding when it occurs.

Change-Id: Idfa4980215cb5489aa94c4ee7e55cdd160ed77d6
Closes-Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1792375

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I45b6a99b96436e12081cc7a021779b832c664c88

commit_message:
Correct use of force_tcg with libguestfs

Use force_tcg for virt-resize and virt-customize if the
libguestfs-test-tool fails.

Also dump virt-resize, virt-customize and libguestfs-test-tools to
log files.

Change-Id: I767da273629d3e8979ea980eade47e67409e090b
Related-Bug: #1743749

[{'created': '2019-04-03 13:16:21.000000000', 'message': 'Use hostname of machine for ``binding_host_id``

The current implementation relies on DNS to resolve the hostname
associated with the ``private-address`` IP of the unit.

This does not always provide a reliable result.

Change-Id: I3a3a3cddd35354944196a155ca0b239e680333d3
Closes-Bug: #1823000
'}]
commit_message:
Use hostname of machine for ``binding_host_id``

The current implementation relies on DNS to resolve the hostname
associated with the ``private-address`` IP of the unit.

This does not always provide a reliable result.

Change-Id: I3a3a3cddd35354944196a155ca0b239e680333d3
Closes-Bug: #1823000

[{'created': '2019-03-24 21:07:13.000000000', 'message': 'Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: Icaa4c41666e41693baba9db89c6ed2709e2836d1
'}]
commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: Icaa4c41666e41693baba9db89c6ed2709e2836d1

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-02 11:55:13.000000000', 'message': '[Queens-only] Restart Erlang VM on undercloud upgrade

When running an undercloud upgrade, yum can upgrade to a newer
major version of Erlang, and it doesn't restart the running
Erlang Port Mapper Daemon (epmd).

When upgrading from Erlang 18 to Erlang 19, the Erlang VM
implements differently calls to OS commands [1]. This confuses
RabbitMQ recurring monitoring process:

    ERROR: "Free disk space monitor encountered an error (e.g. failed to parse output from OS tools):

and also makes command line tools link management plugin fail
until epmd is restarted:

    $ rabbitmq-plugins list -E -m
    Error: invalid parameter: []

Since undercloud ugprade restarts RabbitMQ anyway, make sure to
also stop the running Erlang VM and let RabbitMQ restart it
automatically during the upgrade.

We only do that for Queens because starting Rocky, RabbitMQ
is containerized and thus always restart both RabbitMQ and
Erlang VM on container image updates.

[1] https://github.com/erlang/otp/commit/200247f972b012ced0c4b2c6611f091af66ebedd

Change-Id: I6f486b0b70f19d8b4916ef500675c0739939e060
Closes-Bug: #1822120
Co-Authored-By: Peter Lemenkov <plemenko@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I6f486b0b70f19d8b4916ef500675c0739939e060
Closes-Bug: #1822120

'}, {'created': '2019-04-03 07:33:23.000000000', 'message': '[Queens-only] Restart Erlang VM on undercloud upgrade

major version of Erlang, and it doesn't restart the running
Erlang Port Mapper Daemon (epmd) nor RabbitMQ.

When upgrading from Erlang 18 to Erlang 19, the Erlang VM

    ERROR: "Free disk space monitor encountered an error (e.g. failed to parse output from OS tools):

and also makes command line tools link management plugin fail
until epmd is restarted:

    $ rabbitmq-plugins list -E -m
    Error: invalid parameter: []

Erlang VM on container image updates.

[1] https://github.com/erlang/otp/commit/200247f972b012ced0c4b2c6611f091af66ebedd

Change-Id: I6f486b0b70f19d8b4916ef500675c0739939e060
Closes-Bug: #1822120
Co-Authored-By: Peter Lemenkov <plemenko@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
[Queens-only] Restart Erlang VM on undercloud upgrade

When running an undercloud upgrade, yum can upgrade to a newer
major version of Erlang, and it doesn't restart the running
Erlang Port Mapper Daemon (epmd) nor RabbitMQ.

When upgrading from Erlang 18 to Erlang 19, the Erlang VM
implements differently calls to OS commands [1]. This confuses
RabbitMQ recurring monitoring process:

    ERROR: "Free disk space monitor encountered an error (e.g. failed to parse output from OS tools):

and also makes command line tools link management plugin fail
until epmd is restarted:

    $ rabbitmq-plugins list -E -m
    Error: invalid parameter: []

Make sure to restart both epmd and RabbitMQ if they are running,
to start the upgrade from a valid erlang runtime.

We only do that for Queens because starting Rocky, RabbitMQ
is containerized and thus always restart both RabbitMQ and
Erlang VM on container image updates.

[1] https://github.com/erlang/otp/commit/200247f972b012ced0c4b2c6611f091af66ebedd

Change-Id: I6f486b0b70f19d8b4916ef500675c0739939e060
Closes-Bug: #1822120
Co-Authored-By: Peter Lemenkov <plemenko@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove "supports_recreate" from capabilities

The changeset to close bug 1821891 added the
field "supports_evacuate" in the driver
capabilities without removing "supports_recreate",
which was the old field for the same.

Change-Id: If93ed659dfcbe7dc2820e6110c5878adaf0de158
Closes-Bug: #1822853
(cherry picked from commit 7a8516ffb521b31746a816dc01ed09eb53676160)

commit_message:
Deploy steps playbook: add a step0 tag

All the config-download steps can be run using a `stepX` tag with
ansible-playbook, except step 0. This patch adds the tag.

Change-Id: Ida335e7b7efef6c2a5a8b7a23b09f13588c7695a

Frank, this is not an official OpenStack project - I thought i18n only translates OpenStack projects.

Also, that project needs some more love, have a look at the slow pace of commits - https://review.openstack.org/#/q/project:openstack/four-opens . The book is not done AFAIU.'}, {'account_id': 17765, 'date': '2019-01-18 12:18:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Frank, this is not an official OpenStack project - I thought i18n

 > 
 > Also, that project needs some more love, have a look at the slow
 > pace of commits - https://review.openstack.org/#/q/project:openstack/four-opens
 > . The book is not done AFAIU.

@Andreas: I know, nevertheless OSF pushs the topic to one of the w.o.o front page, with this ugly link to the git repo of the book. I think we can give more love to allow the usage of our infrastructure for translation and publishing. Otherwise it needs a manually import of po files and a manually shipping back to the repo.
And anyway, I've read so many headlines for four-opens and want to move definitly forward. Maybe Chris or Jimmy can clarify, because we translated also other stuff from OSF."}, {'account_id': 10278, 'date': '2019-01-18 14:00:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Let's wait - repo is not ready yet, see Jimmy's comment"}, {'account_id': 17765, 'date': '2019-04-03 14:31:18.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

no progress'}]

commit_message:
Disable beaker jobs for now

The centos packaging is broken because congress recently bumped their
psycopg2 requirement to version >= 2.7 but RDO only ships version 2.5.
Basically installing congress doesn't seem to be working on centos or
ubuntu at the moment so we need to kill the beaker jobs so we can land
the stein branch bits.

Change-Id: Iccbf3dbff9f21c1ee2dc075c1324670d66bc0aa7
(cherry picked from commit dfedf04e899d6ef13509a7588d7038d8a9bc4a1d)

commit_message:
basic polling JSON ingester

New PollingJsonIngester class which polls API end points as defined
in YAML configs and populates configured postgreSQL database with
JSON data.

Change-Id: I8d22cf8d2da1b1c2e99b8e0cd2d60f3ef71e2def
partially-implements: bp json-data-model

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-25 12:33:50.000000000', 'message': "Check configuration file permissions in CI

Typically, non-executable files should have 660 or 600 and executable
files and directories should have 770. All should be owned by the
'config_owner_user' and 'config_owner_group' variables.

Change-Id: Icdbabf36e284b9030017a0dc07b9dc81a37758ab
"}, {'created': '2019-03-25 15:43:57.000000000', 'message': "Check configuration file permissions in CI

Typically, non-executable files should have 660 or 600 and executable
files and directories should have 770. All should be owned by the
'config_owner_user' and 'config_owner_group' variables.

This change adds a script to check the owner and permissions of config
files under /etc/kolla, and runs it at the end of CI jobs.

Change-Id: Icdbabf36e284b9030017a0dc07b9dc81a37758ab
Related-Bug: #1821579
"}, {'created': '2019-03-25 18:19:18.000000000', 'message': "Check configuration file permissions in CI

Typically, non-executable files should have 660 or 600 and executable
files and directories should have 770. All should be owned by the

commit_message:
Check configuration file permissions in CI

Typically, non-executable files should have 660 or 600 and executable
files and directories should have 770. All should be owned by the
'config_owner_user' and 'config_owner_group' variables.

This change adds a script to check the owner and permissions of config
files under /etc/kolla, and runs it at the end of CI jobs.

Change-Id: Icdbabf36e284b9030017a0dc07b9dc81a37758ab
Related-Bug: #1821579

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-28 17:31:45.000000000', 'message': "Add support for pacemaker-remotes

This change adds support for pacmaker-remots joining the cluster
via the pacemaher-remote relation. The pacemaker-remotes can
advertise whether they should host resources. If the
pacemaker-remotes are only being used for failure detection
(as is the case with masakari host monitors) then they
will not host resources.

Pacemaker remotes are managed in the cluster as resources
which nominally run on a member in the main cluster. The
resource that corresponds to the pacemaker-remote is managed
via configure_pacemaker_remotes and configure_pacemaker_remote
functions.

If the pacemaker-remotes should not run resources then the
cluster needs to be switched to an opt-in cluster. In an
opt-in cluster location rules are needed to explicitly
allow a resource to run on a specific node. This behaviour
is controlled via the global cluster parameter 'symmetric-cluster'
this is set via the new method set_cluster_symmetry. The method
add_location_rules_for_local_nodes is used for creating these
explicit rules.

Change-Id: I0a66cfb1ecad02c2b185c5e6402e77f713d25f8b

commit_message:
Add support for pacemaker-remotes

This change adds support for pacmaker-remots joining the cluster
via the pacemaher-remote relation. The pacemaker-remotes can
advertise whether they should host resources. If the
pacemaker-remotes are only being used for failure detection
(as is the case with masakari host monitors) then they
will not host resources.

Pacemaker remotes are managed in the cluster as resources
which nominally run on a member in the main cluster. The
resource that corresponds to the pacemaker-remote is managed
via configure_pacemaker_remotes and configure_pacemaker_remote
functions.

If the pacemaker-remotes should not run resources then the
cluster needs to be switched to an opt-in cluster. In an
opt-in cluster location rules are needed to explicitly
allow a resource to run on a specific node. This behaviour
is controlled via the global cluster parameter 'symmetric-cluster'
this is set via the new method set_cluster_symmetry. The method
add_location_rules_for_local_nodes is used for creating these
explicit rules.

Change-Id: I0a66cfb1ecad02c2b185c5e6402e77f713d25f8b

git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: I6a7ca7d3ec8f3a3f7bf332aa1585e84e2e4483a1

[{'created': '2019-03-28 17:31:45.000000000', 'message': "New member_ready state in peer relation

This change adds a new 'member_ready' state to the peer relation.
This purpose of this is to indicate that a unit has rendered its
configuration and started its services. This is distinct from the
existing 'ready' indicator. 'ready' indicates that the unit can
render its config and start services and ensures that all units are
present prior to starting services. This seems to safe guard
against units starting to early and forming single node clusters or
small clusters with a sub-set of units. The 'member_ready' flag
is later in the process and if it is set it shows that this unit
has joined the cluster and can be referenceed explicitly in any
resource configuration.

commit_message:
New member_ready state in peer relation

This change adds a new 'member_ready' state to the peer relation.
This purpose of this is to indicate that a unit has rendered its
configuration and started its services. This is distinct from the
existing 'ready' indicator. 'ready' indicates that the unit can
render its config and start services and ensures that all units are
present prior to starting services. This seems to safe guard
against units starting to early and forming single node clusters or
small clusters with a sub-set of units. The 'member_ready' flag
is later in the process and if it is set it shows that this unit
has joined the cluster and can be referenceed explicitly in any
resource configuration.

Change-Id: I80d42a628a3fe51bc6f8d02610031afd9386d7a4

commit_message:
Use XML to get node list

The current list_nodes command tries to parse the output of
"crm node list" to get a list of nodes. But the output is messy if
remote nodes are present so use "crm node status" to get properly
formatted XML which can be reliably parsed.

Change-Id: Iea7ef3dca194e7440dc2cde2624d07e990006685

commit_message:
Disable beaker jobs for now

The centos packaging is broken because congress recently bumped their
psycopg2 requirement to version >= 2.7 but RDO only ships version 2.5.
Basically installing congress doesn't seem to be working on centos or
ubuntu at the moment so we need to kill the beaker jobs so we can land
the stein branch bits.

Change-Id: Iccbf3dbff9f21c1ee2dc075c1324670d66bc0aa7

commit_message:
Add pacemaker authkey

To work with pacemaker remotes all pacemaker nodes (including the
remotes) need to share a common key in the same way that corosync
does. This change allows a user to set a pacemaker key via config
in the same way as corosync. If the pacemaker key value is unset
then the corosync key is user.

Change-Id: I75247e7f3af29fc0907a94ae8e1678bdb9ee64e2

commit_message:
Support hacluster using peer-availability relation

Add support for the hacluster charm to be related to a principle
using the juju-info interface using the peer-availability relation.
This is useful in the situation where a cluster without any resources
is needed.

Change-Id: Ibd03ba7923cfd2c412d5f772cf385a21c423e5af

commit_message:
tempest: don't use DVR with FWaaS v1

When tempest creates routers for the FWaaS v1 scenario test cases,
if DVR is enabled by default for routers, these test cases will
fail. This commit adds some logic to create centralized routers
explicitly for those test cases, or skip the test cases if a
DVR router is already provided via the `network.public_router_id`
option.

This commit also uses admin tempest credentials to create routers,
because this is required to access the distributed router option.

Change-Id: I81269a499f805134a9368f2774320de972f9c24c

messages:
[{'account_id': 22595, 'date': '2019-03-26 19:02:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12860, 'date': '2019-04-03 02:56:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hello, Is there any bug trace for this or gate failure log?'}, {'account_id': 22595, 'date': '2019-04-03 14:05:36.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This fix isn't as simple as I first thought. Only the admin has the ability to control the distributed vs. centralized aspect of a router (rule:create_router:distributed in the policy). If we use the admin account to create the router, then we must also use the same account to plug interfaces into  it."}, {'account_id': 22595, 'date': '2019-04-03 14:06:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Hello, Is there any bug trace for this or gate failure log?

I only have an old bug comment stating that floating IPs cannot and should not be used in combination with VPNaaS: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1476469/comments/4

I'm using DVR by default and this test isn't passing for me. When switching the default router type to centralized, it passes."}]

will fail. This commit adds some logic to create centralized
routers explicitly for those test cases.

Change-Id: I00d64aaaae6822a8e82a269fb8275ff460d64641
"}]
commit_message:
tempest: don't use DVR routers

When tempest creates routers for the scenario test cases,
if DVR is enabled by default for routers, these test cases
will fail. This commit adds some logic to create centralized
routers explicitly for those test cases.

Change-Id: I00d64aaaae6822a8e82a269fb8275ff460d64641

commit_message:
Remove "supports_recreate" from capabilities

The changeset to close bug 1821891 added the
field "supports_evacuate" in the driver
capabilities without removing "supports_recreate",
which was the old field for the same.

Change-Id: If93ed659dfcbe7dc2820e6110c5878adaf0de158
Closes-Bug: #1822853

commit_message:
Share snapshot image membership with instance owner

Stop overwriting the is_public image metadata field so that nova
can handle this. For more information, see [1].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-January/001726.html

Change-Id: If5c08dd28b61de8fad66d3ba9ec858aaa2fa8287
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/630769
Closes-Bug: #1675791

commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: I02b88da25e80c71780c1ddb6e6ecf94cd179c90d

commit_message:
Bootstrap the v2 API

This adds a v2 API root to CloudKitty. An example endpoint along with some
developer documentation has been added. The API root is now served with Flask
instead of pecan.

Change-Id: I4ede52dae531631f7fe708400def01bc08a64dec
Story: 2004208
Task: 27717
Task: 27718
Task: 27719

commit_message:
Fix up config file permissions on the host

Several config file permissions are incorrect on the host. In general,
files should be 0660, and directories and executables 0770.

Change-Id: Id276ac1864f280554e98b937f2845bb424d521de
Closes-Bug: #1821579

commit_message:
Improve tempest plugins installation

Instead of ignoring installation failure, new code would fail if
tempest plugins cannot be installed and also work if there are
no plugins specified.

Change-Id: Ic5ea1bf75cd30f8af6d9a3586a0073ff5c54cb27
Related-Bug: #1787912

commit_message:
Fix bug preventing forbidden traits from working

Modifies _clean_empties function to take forbidden traits into account
in addition to required traits.

Added unit test test_resources_from_request_spec_flavor_forbidden_trait
to test that a single forbidden trait doesn't get lost in the
resources_from_request_spec function.

Also updated the functional test
test_flavor_forbidden_traits_based_scheduling to do the right thing.

Change-Id: I491b10c9c202baae4a37034848147f910a50eebf
Closes-Bug: #1821824

commit_message:
Generate inventory for mistral ssh

All of the calls to get_tripleo_ansible_inventory will then pass this
inventory to mistral, so the inventory entry for the undercloud needs
to use ssh as the connection.

Change-Id: I68ad49f103af79ab4b82b499b8620af9470f1ef9
Closes-Bug: #1822518
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/649459/

[{'created': '2019-04-02 17:59:40.000000000', 'message': 'DevStack: Fix Amphora->kubelet port connectivity

Due to some unknown changes in either Neutron, Octavia or anything else,
we lost the Amphora->kubelet port connectivity that was crucial for our
K8s API LB to function.

To work around this this commit adds --subnet-id argument when creating
LB member. This makes Octavia attach pod subnet to the Amphora VM. In
order to make this work a security group that accepts traffic from pod
subnet is also added to kubelet port.

commit_message:
DevStack: Fix Amphora->kubelet port connectivity

Due to some unknown changes in either Neutron, Octavia or anything else,
we lost the Amphora->kubelet port connectivity that was crucial for our
K8s API LB to function.

To work around this this commit adds --subnet-id argument when creating
LB member. This makes Octavia attach pod subnet to the Amphora VM. In
order to make this work a security group that accepts traffic from pod
subnet is also added to kubelet port.

Change-Id: I764f8fd1d53ba5936c68519583e973188b82db08
Closes-Bug: 1822862

commit_message:
Remove mox in unit/network/test_neutronv2.py (5)

Replace mox with mock
in test methods in the TestNeutronv2Portbinding class
in nova/tests/unit/network/test_neutronv2.py.

Then all test methods in the TestPortBindingWithMock class
are moved to the TestNeutronv2Portbinding class.

Subsequent patches will replace mox in other test cases.

Change-Id: I1788389d11a9f3b6b0bd0b75d2184be9e90983bb
Implements: blueprint mox-removal-train

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-11 00:49:15.000000000', 'message': "Remove mox in unit/network/test_neutronv2.py (4)

Replace mox with mock
in nova/tests/unit/network/test_neutronv2.py.

This patch adds the '_test_allocate_for_instance_with_virtual_interface'
method in the _TestNeutronv2Common class for test cases using mock
instead of the '_allocate_for_instance' method
in the TestNeutronv2Base class.

The '_allocate_for_instance' method will be removed
when replacing mox is completed in test methods using
the '_allocate_for_instance' method.

This patch moves the following methods in the TestNeutronv2 class
to the TestNeutronv2WithMock class.

* test_allocate_for_instance_1
* test_allocate_for_instance_accepts_macs_kwargs_None
* test_allocate_for_instance_accepts_macs_kwargs_set
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_mac_added_to_port
* test_allocate_for_instance_accepts_only_portid
* test_allocate_for_instance_two_macs_two_networks
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_requested_non_available_network
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_requested_networks
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_no_subnet_defined
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_requested_networks_with_fixedip
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_requested_networks_with_port
* test_allocate_for_instance_second_time
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_requested_networks_duplicates
* test_allocate_for_instance_requested_networks_duplicates_port
* test_allocate_for_instance_requested_networks_duplicates_combo

Subsequent patches will replace mox in other test cases.

Change-Id: Ibbc004a9175462dc31d30ab44b188de867d94d57
Implements: blueprint mox-removal

commit_message:
Remove mox in unit/network/test_neutronv2.py (4)

Replace mox with mock
in nova/tests/unit/network/test_neutronv2.py.

This patch adds the '_test_allocate_for_instance_with_virtual_interface'
method in the _TestNeutronv2Common class for test cases using mock
instead of the '_allocate_for_instance' method
in the TestNeutronv2Base class.

The '_allocate_for_instance' method will be removed
when replacing mox is completed in test methods using
the '_allocate_for_instance' method.

This patch moves the following methods in the TestNeutronv2 class
to the TestNeutronv2WithMock class.

* test_allocate_for_instance_1
* test_allocate_for_instance_accepts_macs_kwargs_None
* test_allocate_for_instance_accepts_macs_kwargs_set
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_mac_added_to_port
* test_allocate_for_instance_accepts_only_portid
* test_allocate_for_instance_two_macs_two_networks
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_requested_non_available_network
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_requested_networks
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_no_subnet_defined
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_requested_networks_with_fixedip
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_requested_networks_with_port
* test_allocate_for_instance_second_time
* test_allocate_for_instance_with_requested_networks_duplicates
* test_allocate_for_instance_requested_networks_duplicates_port
* test_allocate_for_instance_requested_networks_duplicates_combo

Subsequent patches will replace mox in other test cases.

Change-Id: Ibbc004a9175462dc31d30ab44b188de867d94d57
Implements: blueprint mox-removal-train

commit_message:
Add tempest_test_whitelist to allowed_override

This patch add tempest_test_whitelist to allowed_overrides list, as well
as the list of default tempest tests to be executed by os_tempest job.
This new variable is required to os_tempest based job get executed
properly.

https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/900?kanban-status=1447275
Change-Id: Id67193f1a7b9a5e93c2a2ba687da920d147c9ab0

commit_message:
Fix a few pylint warnings

Removed a duplicate dict key, fixed an expression that was
unassigned and added whitelist_externals for pep8 environment
since it's calling mkdir.

Change-Id: Ia901ac0ebd6f45620c80e4b8489f4774bf51d657

commit_message:
Docs: emulator threads: clarify expected behavior

This patch adds a table of possible extra-spec/cpu_shared_set
combinations, and lists the expected behavior of instance emulator
threads for each case. This is an improvement over the previous doc,
which incorrectly implied that `share` was the default policy value,
and only covered what happens if cpu_shared_set is set.

Change-Id: Ia56607d0b70d5f46159b57ee1092ba0e37a02270

Those ports, whose device-owner is router_ha_interface,

commit_message:
Don't allow deletion of HA port of router

When the neutron_lbaas is configurated and enabled,
the created router will be HA router. Every router
instance will has a HA port which to keep them alived.
Those ports, whose device-owner is router_ha_interface,
will shown on page.
But there will throw an NotFound error when deleting them.
IMO, it is enough for user to known them exist. we
don't need to operate them for they only using by router
instance.

Change-Id: I276b5754b936d03b87b1e8ef39097a130e309211

commit_message:
Add settable `IndicatorLED` property to the `Drive` resource

Adds ``IndicatorLED`` property to the ``Drive`` resource. The state
of the LED can be read and can be changed via the
``.set_indicator_led()`` method of the ``Drive`` class.

Change-Id: Ief81d5315dee9a98d69223ca01de11ef757a348c
Story: 2005342
Task: 30290

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-03 06:36:15.000000000', 'message': "Normalize operation messages into capital case

Operation messages use sentence case in html files
(e.g. 'Create port') while capital case in js files
(e.g. 'Create Port'). Normalize them to use capital case in order
not to generate different translation items for same message.

Change-Id: I1a40859447eb6ba53eef19521e110f786380a00b
"}]
commit_message:
Normalize operation messages into capital case

Operation messages use sentence case in html files
(e.g. 'Create port') while capital case in js files
(e.g. 'Create Port'). Normalize them to use capital case in order
not to generate different translation items for same message.

Change-Id: I1a40859447eb6ba53eef19521e110f786380a00b

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-21 00:07:04.000000000', 'message': 'Backup /etc/os-net-config/config.json when os-net-config runs

Currently os-net-config is called by TripleO with either the
config.json or element_config.json configuration, and then
the configuration file is deleted after os-net-config runs.
This makes it more difficult to troubleshoot a deployment,
since there is no reference file for the network config
which was applied. This change renames the file and
appends the date_time to the file name to preserve the file
for troubleshooting.

Closes-bug: 1816920
Change-Id: I79a6c5428958c1508eb16f91096cb96d7ddc03f6

commit_message:
Backup /etc/os-net-config/config.json when os-net-config runs

Currently os-net-config is called by TripleO with either the
config.json or element_config.json configuration, and then
the configuration file is deleted after os-net-config runs.
This makes it more difficult to troubleshoot a deployment,
since there is no reference file for the network config
which was applied. This change renames the file and
appends the date_time to the file name to preserve the file
for troubleshooting.

Closes-bug: 1816920
Change-Id: I79a6c5428958c1508eb16f91096cb96d7ddc03f6

[{'created': '2019-03-24 21:16:30.000000000', 'message': 'Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: Ia2558bbfac2e676774aa0844fba812c8be3c8075
'}]
commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: Ia2558bbfac2e676774aa0844fba812c8be3c8075

commit_message:
Fix failure to mount cephfs

Commit 2f6b1c6890cf7ea6b0dd33ac219646e4dcaf1fd6 changed the way the
cephfs source path was generated and dropped the source path component,
keeping only the list of IPs and ports. This results in failures to
mount cephfs with the following message:

    source mount path was not specified
    failed to resolve source

Change-Id: I94d18ec064971870264ae8d0b279564f2172e548
Closes-Bug: #1819502
(cherry picked from commit 42dd7784de8d1b22cf18a7aefbc6783efe4bd7ea)

commit_message:
Create /volumes when using external ceph

Currently we only create the /volumes directory when
using the kolla-ansible bundled ceph. This extends the
functionality to external ceph.

Note: In addition to the cherry-picked commit, we add jmespath to
requirements as it is required for the json_query filter, with a minimum
version of 0.9.3 to match lower-constraints.txt.

Change-Id: I1e9a40e4ee893a53f04909ef7835be005c9b5276
Closes-Bug: #1778720
(cherry picked from commit 2f6b1c6890cf7ea6b0dd33ac219646e4dcaf1fd6)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-06 17:33:45.000000000', 'message': "De-cruft compute manager live migration

This is pretty basic and only does two things:

1. Uses the errors_out_migration decorator on the
   live_migration method so that any errors in that
   method will result in the migration status changing
   to 'error' rather than only RuntimeErrors.

2. Since we dropped RPC 4.x compability the MigrateData
   parameter to _do_live_migration is required, so drop
   a condition on it being None and also DRY up and
   comment on setting migrate_data.migration which is
   needed for _post_live_migration and
   _rollback_live_migration.

Change-Id: Idfab9c1cac54d0af7ea3e2a58e616298282ca2f9
"}]
commit_message:
De-cruft compute manager live migration

This is pretty basic and only does two things:

1. Uses the errors_out_migration decorator on the
   live_migration method so that any errors in that
   method will result in the migration status changing
   to 'error' rather than only RuntimeErrors.

2. Since we dropped RPC 4.x compability the MigrateData
   parameter to _do_live_migration is required, so drop
   a condition on it being None and also DRY up and
   comment on setting migrate_data.migration which is
   needed for _post_live_migration and
   _rollback_live_migration.

Change-Id: Idfab9c1cac54d0af7ea3e2a58e616298282ca2f9

node capabilities.

commit_message:
Fix capabilities passed as string in agent prepare

The value of capabilities can be either a string or a dict.
There is a function to parse its value and provide a correct
output as expected and it should always be used when reading
node capabilities.

Change-Id: I789fffd5f67eddbe5058581f13d75320ca712897
Story: 2005280
Task: 30133
(cherry picked from commit 93a40e3fc7a8187c0444c1aae93a52beb5c68b4b)

commit_message:
Bump OpenStack service versions

Update bifrost from 5.0.1 to 5.0.2
Update cinder from 12.0.4 to 12.0.5
Update designate-dashboard from 6.0.0 to 6.0.1
Update heat-dashboard from 1.0.2 to 1.0.3
Update ironic from 10.1.6 to 10.1.8
Update ironic-inspector from 7.2.1 to 7.2.3
Update magnum from 6.2.0 to 6.3.0
Update manila from 6.0.2 to 6.2.0
Update mistral from 6.0.5 to 6.0.6
Update nova from 17.0.7 to 17.0.10
Update octavia from 2.0.2 to 2.0.4
Update swift from 2.17.0 to 2.17.1

Change-Id: I1b5dec1887dc4714065acc947804a92103616be9

commit_message:
Move RabbitMQ handling into a separate role and support disabling it

Ironic can use JSON RPC and ironic-inspector is compatible with fake:// transport.
Keystone does not seem to need oslo.messaging at all. This change moves
RabbitMQ bits to a separate role, but keeps it enabled until the next patch.

Change-Id: I096a347e3bf6270167d35b7c1cf46834ae2d4ece

commit_message:
exclude locked instances

Usually, the end users would have some sensitive applications, like
database servers. This kind of instances doesn't have a special
identification to the administrator, while the end users wouldn't
like to migrate them frequently when optimizing.
We suggest that the end users lock their sensitive instances.
When optimizing, Watcher would execute no migrations to such
locked instances.

Change-Id: I10fb96f260f6a9e79194ad17b57efbf6de5d2a0f
Implements:blueprint exclude-locked-instances

commit_message:
Implement push flag for buildah

KollaBuilder is able to bypass container push we implement the same
thing here with the container_push flag in the constructor.

Related-Bug: #1822752

Change-Id: I588154ad450bab13d3b20b77126d55ded5acd433

Currently nova-powervm driver is not supporting
evacuate. And so Virtual Machine evacuate fails
with the exception InstanceEvacuateNotSupported.
So add supports_evacuate=True to capabilities.

Change-Id: I20a9a805831a8816fd847a2559fd65665dc67a78
Closes-Bug: #1821891
(cherry picked from commit 2819a9cc625b2f11899a18b8257ad3d58eca9efd)
'}]
commit_message:
Add supports_evacuate=True to capabilities

Currently nova-powervm driver is not supporting
evacuate. And so Virtual Machine evacuate fails
with the exception InstanceEvacuateNotSupported.
So add supports_evacuate=True to capabilities.

Change-Id: I20a9a805831a8816fd847a2559fd65665dc67a78
Closes-Bug: #1821891
(cherry picked from commit 2819a9cc625b2f11899a18b8257ad3d58eca9efd)

commit_message:
Add '<div class="form-group">'

On create keypair form in launch instance workflow,
if you enter an existing name,
the key type field will also display a red error.

Change-Id: I136135a22087316b4697d6755d36e0cf995d4685
Closes-Bug: #1822539

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-05 14:20:20.000000000', 'message': "Correct lower-constraints.txt and the related tox job

In the review of a similar change in placement [1], it was realized that
the nova lower-constraints tox job probably had the same problems.
Testing revealed this to be the case. This change fixes the job and
updates the related requirements problems accordingly.

The are two main factors at play here:

* The default install_command in tox.ini uses the upper_contraints.txt
  file. When there is more than one constraints.txt they are merged and
  the higher constraints win. Using upper and lower at the same time
  violates the point of lower (which is to indicate the bare minimum
  we are capable of using).

* When usedevelop is true in tox, the command that is run to install the
  current projects code is something like 'python setup.py develop',
  which installs a project's requirements _after_ the install_command has
  run, clobbering the constrained installs. When using pbr,
  'python setup.py install' (used when usedevelop is False) does not do
  this.

Fixing those then makes it possible to use the test to fix the
lower-constraints.txt and *requirements.txt files, changes include:

* Removing packages which show up in lower-constraints.txt but not in
  the created virtualenv. Note that the job only runs unit tests, so
  this may be incomplete. In the placement version of this both unit and
  functional are run. We may want to consider that here.

* Updating cryptography. This version is needed with more recent
  pyopenssl.

* Updated keystonemiddleware. This is needed for some tests which
  confirm passing configuration to the middleware.

* Update psycopg2 to a version that can talk with postgresql 10.

* Add PyJWT, used by zVMCloudConnector

* Update zVMCloudConnector to a version that works with Python 3.5 and
  beyond.

* Update oslo.policy and olso.messaging to versions that work with the
  tests, under Python 3.

NOTE: There is one remaining failing test which it is not clear how to
resolve. 'test_policy_generator_from_command_line' forks a call to
'oslopolicy-policy-generator --namespace nova' which fails because
stevedore fails to pick up nova-based entry points when in a different
process. This is because of the change to usedevelop. Presumably the
test can be changed to not fork, and instead call the generator
directly. Another option is to get rid of it, doesn't seem to do that
much. Input desired.

[1] Id66a28f7ace6fc2adf0e1201d9de5f901234d870

Change-Id: Ic6466b0440a4fe012731a63715cf5d793b6ae4dd

"}, {'created': '2018-12-07 10:28:21.000000000', 'message': "Correct lower-constraints.txt and the related tox job

In the review of a similar change in placement [1], it was realized that
the nova lower-constraints tox job probably had the same problems.
Testing revealed this to be the case. This change fixes the job and
updates the related requirements problems accordingly.

The are two main factors at play here:

* The default install_command in tox.ini uses the upper_contraints.txt
  file. When there is more than one constraints.txt they are merged and
  the higher constraints win. Using upper and lower at the same time
  violates the point of lower (which is to indicate the bare minimum
  we are capable of using).

* When usedevelop is true in tox, the command that is run to install the
  current projects code is something like 'python setup.py develop',
  which installs a project's requirements _after_ the install_command has
  run, clobbering the constrained installs. When using pbr,
  'python setup.py install' (used when usedevelop is False) does not do
  this.

Fixing those then makes it possible to use the test to fix the
lower-constraints.txt and *requirements.txt files, changes include:

* Defining 'usedevelop = False' in the 'lower-constraints' target and
  removing the otherwise superfluous 'skipsdist' global setting to
  ensure requirements aren't clobbered.

* Removing packages which show up in lower-constraints.txt but not in
  the created virtualenv. Note that the job only runs unit tests, so
  this may be incomplete. In the placement version of this both unit and
  functional are run. We may want to consider that here.

* Updating cryptography. This version is needed with more recent
  pyopenssl.

* Updated keystonemiddleware. This is needed for some tests which
  confirm passing configuration to the middleware.

* Update psycopg2 to a version that can talk with postgresql 10.

* Add PyJWT, used by zVMCloudConnector

* Update zVMCloudConnector to a version that works with Python 3.5 and
  beyond.

* Update oslo.policy and olso.messaging to versions that work with the
  tests, under Python 3.

* Updating eventlet to a version that works well with the tests, in
  Python 2. Note that the lower-constraints job tests with the default
  basepython, which is 3 now, and there are definite differences between
  package requirements between the two versions. Local testing was done
  to try to make sure that the file is completely for the lower version.

NOTE: There a test is removed because it cannot work in the
lower-constraints context: 'test_policy_generator_from_command_line'
forks a call to 'oslopolicy-policy-generator --namespace nova' which
fails because stevedore fails to pick up nova-based entry points when
in a different process. This is because of the change to usedevelop.
After discussion with the original author of the test removal was
considered an acceptable choice.

The depends-on points to a zuul job change which updates the
lower-constraints job to use python 3.6.

[1] Id66a28f7ace6fc2adf0e1201d9de5f901234d870

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/623229
Change-Id: Ic6466b0440a4fe012731a63715cf5d793b6ae4dd

the nova lower-constraints tox job probably had the same problems.
Testing revealed this to be the case. This change fixes the job and
updates the related requirements problems accordingly.

The are two main factors at play here:

* The default install_command in tox.ini uses the upper_contraints.txt

* Defining 'usedevelop = False' in the 'lower-constraints' target and
  removing the otherwise superfluous 'skipsdist' global setting to
  ensure requirements aren't clobbered.

* Removing packages which show up in lower-constraints.txt but not in
  the created virtualenv. Note that the job only runs unit tests, so
  this may be incomplete. In the placement version of this both unit and
  functional are run. We may want to consider that here.

* Updating cryptography. This version is needed with more recent
  pyopenssl.

* Updated keystonemiddleware. This is needed for some tests which
  confirm passing configuration to the middleware.

* Update psycopg2 to a version that can talk with postgresql 10.

* Add PyJWT, used by zVMCloudConnector

* Update zVMCloudConnector to a version that works with Python 3.5 and
  beyond.

* Update oslo.policy and olso.messaging to versions that work with the
  tests, under Python 3.

* Updating eventlet to a version that works well with the tests, in
  Python 2. Note that the lower-constraints job tests with the default
  basepython, which is 3 now, and there are definite differences between
  package requirements between the two versions. Local testing was done
  to try to make sure that the file is completely for the lower version.

NOTE: There a test is removed because it cannot work in the
lower-constraints context: 'test_policy_generator_from_command_line'
forks a call to 'oslopolicy-policy-generator --namespace nova' which
fails because stevedore fails to pick up nova-based entry points when
in a different process. This is because of the change to usedevelop.
After discussion with the original author of the test removal was
considered an acceptable choice.

The depends-on points to a zuul job change which updates the
lower-constraints job to use python 3.6.

[1] Id66a28f7ace6fc2adf0e1201d9de5f901234d870

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/623229
Change-Id: Ic6466b0440a4fe012731a63715cf5d793b6ae4dd
"}, {'created': '2019-02-14 10:02:56.000000000', 'message': "Correct lower-constraints.txt and the related tox job

In the review of a similar change in placement [1], it was realized that
the nova lower-constraints tox job probably had the same problems.
Testing revealed this to be the case. This change fixes the job and
updates the related requirements problems accordingly.

The are two main factors at play here:

* The default install_command in tox.ini uses the upper_contraints.txt
  file. When there is more than one constraints.txt they are merged and
  the higher constraints win. Using upper and lower at the same time
  violates the point of lower (which is to indicate the bare minimum
  we are capable of using).

* When usedevelop is true in tox, the command that is run to install the
  current projects code is something like 'python setup.py develop',
  which installs a project's requirements _after_ the install_command has
  run, clobbering the constrained installs. When using pbr,
  'python setup.py install' (used when usedevelop is False) does not do
  this.

Fixing those then makes it possible to use the test to fix the
lower-constraints.txt and *requirements.txt files, changes include:

* Defining 'usedevelop = False' in the 'lower-constraints' target and
  removing the otherwise superfluous 'skipsdist' global setting to
  ensure requirements aren't clobbered.

* Removing packages which show up in lower-constraints.txt but not in
  the created virtualenv. Note that the job only runs unit tests, so
  this may be incomplete. In the placement version of this both unit and
  functional are run. We may want to consider that here.

* Updating cryptography. This version is needed with more recent
  pyopenssl.

* Updated keystonemiddleware. This is needed for some tests which
  confirm passing configuration to the middleware.

* Update psycopg2 to a version that can talk with postgresql 10.

* Add PyJWT, used by zVMCloudConnector

* Update zVMCloudConnector to a version that works with Python 3.5 and
  beyond.

* Update oslo.policy and olso.messaging to versions that work with the
  tests, under Python 3.

* Updating eventlet to a version that works well with the tests, in
  Python 2. Note that the lower-constraints job tests with the default
  basepython, which is 3 now, and there are definite differences between
  package requirements between the two versions. Local testing was done
  to try to make sure that the file is completely for the lower version.

NOTE: There a test is removed because it cannot work in the
lower-constraints context: 'test_policy_generator_from_command_line'
forks a call to 'oslopolicy-policy-generator --namespace nova' which
fails because stevedore fails to pick up nova-based entry points when
in a different process. This is because of the change to usedevelop.
After discussion with the original author of the test removal was
considered an acceptable choice.

The depends-on points to a zuul job change which updates the
lower-constraints job to use python 3.6.

[1] Id66a28f7ace6fc2adf0e1201d9de5f901234d870

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/623229
Change-Id: Ic6466b0440a4fe012731a63715cf5d793b6ae4dd

"}, {'created': '2019-03-05 13:38:02.000000000', 'message': "Correct lower-constraints.txt and the related tox job

In the review of a similar change in placement [1], it was realized that
the nova lower-constraints tox job probably had the same problems.
Testing revealed this to be the case. This change fixes the job and
updates the related requirements problems accordingly.

The are two main factors at play here:

* The default install_command in tox.ini uses the upper_contraints.txt
  file. When there is more than one constraints.txt they are merged and
  the higher constraints win. Using upper and lower at the same time
  violates the point of lower (which is to indicate the bare minimum
  we are capable of using).

* When usedevelop is true in tox, the command that is run to install the
  current projects code is something like 'python setup.py develop',
  which installs a project's requirements _after_ the install_command has
  run, clobbering the constrained installs. When using pbr,
  'python setup.py install' (used when usedevelop is False) does not do
  this.

Fixing those then makes it possible to use the test to fix the
lower-constraints.txt and *requirements.txt files, changes include:

* Defining 'usedevelop = False' in the 'lower-constraints' target and
  removing the otherwise superfluous 'skipsdist' global setting to
  ensure requirements aren't clobbered.

* Removing packages which show up in lower-constraints.txt but not in
  the created virtualenv. Note that the job only runs unit tests, so
  this may be incomplete. In the placement version of this both unit and
  functional are run. We may want to consider that here.

* Updating cryptography. This version is needed with more recent
  pyopenssl.

* Updated keystonemiddleware. This is needed for some tests which
  confirm passing configuration to the middleware.

* Update psycopg2 to a version that can talk with postgresql 10.

* Add PyJWT, used by zVMCloudConnector

* Update zVMCloudConnector to a version that works with Python 3.5 and
  beyond.

* Update olso.messaging to versions that work with the tests, under
  Python 3.

* Adding missing transitive packages.

* Adjusting alpha-ordering to map to how pip freeze does it.

NOTE: The lower-constraints.txt file makes no commitment to expressing
minimum requirements for anything other than the current basepython.
So the fact that a different set of lower-constraints would be present
if we were using python2 is not relevant. See discussion at [1].

NOTE: A test is removed because it cannot work in the
lower-constraints context: 'test_policy_generator_from_command_line'
forks a call to 'oslopolicy-policy-generator --namespace nova' which
fails because stevedore fails to pick up nova-based entry points when
in a different process. This is because of the change to usedevelop.
After discussion with the original author of the test removal was
considered an acceptable choice.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-dev/%23openstack-dev.2019-03-05.log.html#t2019-03-05T13:28:23

Change-Id: Ic6466b0440a4fe012731a63715cf5d793b6ae4dd

the nova lower-constraints tox job probably had the same problems.
Testing revealed this to be the case. This change fixes the job and
updates the related requirements problems accordingly.

The are two main factors at play here:

* The default install_command in tox.ini uses the upper_contraints.txt
  file. When there is more than one constraints.txt they are merged and
  the higher constraints win. Using upper and lower at the same time
  violates the point of lower (which is to indicate the bare minimum
  we are capable of using).

* When usedevelop is true in tox, the command that is run to install the
  current projects code is something like 'python setup.py develop',
  which installs a project's requirements _after_ the install_command has
  run, clobbering the constrained installs. When using pbr,
  'python setup.py install' (used when usedevelop is False) does not do
  this.

Fixing those then makes it possible to use the test to fix the
lower-constraints.txt and *requirements.txt files, changes include:

* Defining 'usedevelop = False' in the 'lower-constraints' target and
  removing the otherwise superfluous 'skipsdist' global setting to
  ensure requirements aren't clobbered.

* Removing packages which show up in lower-constraints.txt but not in
  the created virtualenv. Note that the job only runs unit tests, so
  this may be incomplete. In the placement version of this both unit and
  functional are run. We may want to consider that here.

* Updating cryptography. This version is needed with more recent
  pyopenssl.

* Updated keystonemiddleware. This is needed for some tests which
  confirm passing configuration to the middleware.

* Update psycopg2 to a version that can talk with postgresql 10.

* Add PyJWT, used by zVMCloudConnector

* Update zVMCloudConnector to a version that works with Python 3.5 and
  beyond.

* Update olso.messaging to versions that work with the tests, under
  Python 3.

* Adding missing transitive packages.

* Adjusting alpha-ordering to map to how pip freeze does it.

* setuptools is removed from requirements.txt because the created
  virtualenv doesn't contain it

NOTE: The lower-constraints.txt file makes no commitment to expressing
minimum requirements for anything other than the current basepython.
So the fact that a different set of lower-constraints would be present
if we were using python2 is not relevant. See discussion at [1].
However, since requirements.txt _is_ used for python2, the
requirements-check gate job requires that enum34 be present in
lower-constraints.txt because it is in requirements.txt.

NOTE: A test is removed because it cannot work in the
lower-constraints context: 'test_policy_generator_from_command_line'
forks a call to 'oslopolicy-policy-generator --namespace nova' which
fails because stevedore fails to pick up nova-based entry points when
in a different process. This is because of the change to usedevelop.
After discussion with the original author of the test removal was
considered an acceptable choice.
