subject: Add graph for number of periodic neutron jobs run
messages:
[{'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-03-12 17:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-03-12 20:49:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

those jobs run exactly once a day. I wonder how this graph will show anything useful at all...'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-03-12 21:05:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

yeah, it was more about making the neutron failure rate dashboard look complete since there was a missing section, but we can drop it'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-03-13 20:14:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I suppose the value is in showing that the number has not dropped to zero for whatever reason.  So you can be sure that it ran.

But if there is already other kinds of monitoring for that sort of thing then this seems superfluous.  Perhaps some other kind of chart could fill the hole, like a "sum of all CI job run counts per time interval" so you can see how many OVN CI jobs are running, or something.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-03-14 14:11:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Andreas - I think Nate's comment is useful - "I suppose the value is in showing that the number has not dropped to zero for whatever reason. So you can be sure that it ran."  For that reason it could be useful just to know they're running even when the failure rate is zero, since we won't know otherwise.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-03-14 18:52:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Let's try it - I wouldn't have pushed this myself and I'm fine to revert if it confuses us more than it helps..."}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-03-15 11:25:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-04-02 05:48:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add graph for number of periodic neutron jobs run

I don't even know how often it runs, but this is the only set
of jobs we don't report any counters for number of runs.

Change-Id: I2a56d6fb83053e8ac5eb605d88987a76b5c21902

commit_message:
Update the network-ovn failure rate dashboard

Change to be like the Neutron dashboard with both failure rate
and number of jobs run per section.  This will allow us to
better understand how the OVN jobs are running over time.

Change-Id: I870f39d6772c451d48254f24f36bdd55d726b883

I have cross checked multiple times and my changes are working perfectly fine'}, {'account_id': 29106, 'date': '2019-02-14 17:45:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 29106, 'date': '2019-02-14 17:47:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 29106, 'date': '2019-02-14 18:47:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 29106, 'date': '2019-02-14 18:51:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2019-02-25 17:21:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I think the idea is sane, but I think the implementation needs to be revisited.  I'd much rather just ingest yaml directly from the values.yaml file instead of chaining conditionals in a helper template function, as that does not scale well."}, {'account_id': 29106, 'date': '2019-02-25 19:44:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > I think the idea is sane, but I think the implementation needs to
 > be revisited.  I'd much rather just ingest yaml directly from the
 > values.yaml file instead of chaining conditionals in a helper
 > template function, as that does not scale well.

Steve,

I don't think we can parse data directly since we have to separate manifest to metadata and parameters; I think following data would solve to directly parse the data from .Values

Please take a look and agree.

storageclass:
  rbd:
    provision_storage_class: true
    provisioner: ceph.com/rbd
    metadata:
      default_storage_class: true
      name: general
    parameters:
      pool: rbd
      admin_id: admin
      ceph_configmap_name: ceph-etc
      admin_secret_name: pvc-ceph-conf-combined-storageclass
      admin_secret_namespace: ceph
      user_id: admin
      user_secret_name: pvc-ceph-client-key
      image_format: "2"
      image_features: layering
  cephfs:
    provision_storage_class: true
    provisioner: ceph.com/cephfs
    metadata:
      name: cephfs
    parameters:
      admin_id: admin
      user_secret_name: pvc-ceph-cephfs-client-key
      admin_secret_name: pvc-ceph-conf-combined-storageclass
      admin_secret_namespace: ceph'}, {'account_id': 29106, 'date': '2019-02-25 21:32:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 29106, 'date': '2019-02-25 22:27:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 29268, 'date': '2019-02-28 09:19:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

While the community outreach is very important to this project. I don't believe this PS will be merged in as there is no specific use case for ATT. However I could be wrong, but I do not think I am."}, {'account_id': 29106, 'date': '2019-03-04 14:10:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

> While the community outreach is very important to this project. I
 > don't believe this PS will be merged in as there is no specific use
 > case for ATT. However I could be wrong, but I do not think I am.

Well, I don't know. but this change will not break anything and it will improve the code. I am not sure why we hesitate to take these kind of improvements"}, {'account_id': 29268, 'date': '2019-03-04 14:16:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

I completely understand your frustration, and I share your concerns as well. You may want to consider forking the project in my opinion.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-03-04 16:25:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

> I completely understand your frustration, and I share your concerns

Hey Kranthi, This looks like some great work. I'll try to review properly today.

I'm a little concerned by some of the review comments here, however - my understanding is that this work is being performed on behalf of AT&T - so am lost as to some to the comments here.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-13 22:12:43.000000000', 'message': 'Improves ceph-provisioner storageclasses

Currently configuring storage classes is static. If
we want to add another storageclass for an exmaple
for harddisk then we have to create another yaml
along with update in .Values.yaml. Using this change
we can create as many storageclasses we want. Change
will basically iterate in loop and apply the values
present in .Values

Change-Id: I3207f047c3f8b1a33dfb97c87b9ea7120b54c4b4
Story: ceph-provisioners-improvement
Signed-off-by: Kranthi Guttikonda <kranthi.guttikonda@b-yond.com>
Signed-off-by: kranthikirang <kranthi.guttikonda@b-yond.com>

commit_message:
Improves ceph-provisioner storageclasses

Currently configuring storage classes is static. If
we want to add another storageclass for an exmaple
for harddisk then we have to create another yaml
along with update in .Values.yaml. Using this change
we can create as many storageclasses we want. Change
will basically iterate in loop and apply the values
present in .Values

At the same time we have to update the changes in
.Values.storageclass.rbd paramert values in all
applicable places

Change-Id: I3207f047c3f8b1a33dfb97c87b9ea7120b54c4b4
Story: ceph-provisioners-improvement
Signed-off-by: Kranthi Guttikonda <kranthi.guttikonda@b-yond.com>
Signed-off-by: kranthikirang <kranthi.guttikonda@b-yond.com>

commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: I446c95827960027cd071d564edbda9f8a78b0f5b

commit_message:
Drop nova-consoleauth service

The nova-consoleauth service was deprecated in Rocky and unless
you have the workarounds section enabled (which we don't), it will
not be used.

This patch drops it and adds tasks to turn it off and remove alll
the unit files.

Change-Id: I14b4870fd652d33a22c0d8480d847570ace8a3a3

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-29 07:28:12.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Invalid fpgconfig options in driver.py

The error info as follows：

$fpgaconf -b 0x5e -d 0x00 -f 0x0 nlb_mode_0.gbs
Invalid cmdline options

fpgaconf Usage:
        fpgaconf [-hvn] [-B <bus>] [-D <device>] [-F <function>] [-S
<socket-id>] <gbs>

Change-Id: Ibaf8f4c4abded6af7526e8cbed4e1578ed287160
'}, {'created': '2019-03-29 08:29:07.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Invalid fpgconfig options in driver.py

The error info as follows：

$fpgaconf -b 0x5e -d 0x00 -f 0x0 nlb_mode_0.gbs
Invalid cmdline options

fpgaconf Usage:
        fpgaconf [-hvn] [-B <bus>] [-D <device>] [-F <function>] [-S
<socket-id>] <gbs>

Change-Id: Ibaf8f4c4abded6af7526e8cbed4e1578ed287160
'}, {'created': '2019-04-02 01:53:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Invalid fpgconfig options in driver.py

The error info as follows by using opae version 1.1.2：

$fpgaconf -b 0x5e -d 0x00 -f 0x0 nlb_mode_0.gbs
Invalid cmdline options

fpgaconf Usage(case 1: initial version)
    fpgaconf [-hvn] [-b <bus>] [-d <device>] [-f <function>] [-s <socket>] <gbs>

fpgaconf Usage(case 2: for example opae version 1.1.2)
    fpgaconf [-hvn] [-B <bus>] [-D <device>] [-F <function>] [-S <socket-id>] <gbs>

so,change the command as follows:
    fpgaconf --bus 0x05 --device 0x00 --function 0x0 nlb_mode_0.gbs

Change-Id: Ibaf8f4c4abded6af7526e8cbed4e1578ed287160
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Invalid fpgconfig options in driver.py

The error info as follows by using opae version 1.1.2：

$fpgaconf -b 0x5e -d 0x00 -f 0x0 nlb_mode_0.gbs
Invalid cmdline options

fpgaconf Usage(case 1: initial version)
    fpgaconf [-hvn] [-b <bus>] [-d <device>] [-f <function>] [-s <socket>] <gbs>

fpgaconf Usage(case 2: for example opae version 1.1.2)
    fpgaconf [-hvn] [-B <bus>] [-D <device>] [-F <function>] [-S <socket-id>] <gbs>

so,change the command as follows:
    fpgaconf --bus 0x05 --device 0x00 --function 0x0 nlb_mode_0.gbs

Change-Id: Ibaf8f4c4abded6af7526e8cbed4e1578ed287160

commit_message:
i18n: Extract strings from template files

Previously babel-django.cfg was configured to look up
template files only in $TOP_DIR/templates.
Templates dierctories in deeper directories
are not covered and all template files are located there.
As a result, Django templates cannot be translated.

Change-Id: I8c662ee2358afbf120464fdffeb72f8515e5a49c

commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: I6337d85cfb5bccddb009ed27e82b5ce37d0b139c

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-11 18:59:09.000000000', 'message': "Fix the subprocess invocation of neutron-l3-agent

neutron-l3-agent tries to invoke neutron-keepalived-state-change
from it's PATH. The venv's bin directory is not part of the
default PATH of the neutron-l3-agent, hence the invocation fails.
This change adds the venv's bin directory to the PATH of
neutron-l3-agent.

To the best of my knowledge this is currently the only script
which is invoked and shipped by neutron itself [1]. Neutron expects
quite a few binaries in it's PATH, however other expected binaries
are typically system packages (e.g. radvd) [2].

Sadly, the PATH can not easily be extended, hence all non venv-bin
directories from the PATH are a 'one-time snapshot' from a quite
common set of directories across all common linux distributions.

[1]
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/search?q=%22cmd+%3D+%27neutron-%22&unscoped_q=%22cmd+%3D+%27neutron-%22
[2]
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/search?q=external_process.ProcessManager&unscoped_q=external_process.ProcessManager

Depends-On: I504a8270be1ddf2f24ab3ad3b4f2f4ca9c990470
Change-Id: I38bb573468dd4c57523cc1a5ff2448009ee2b216
"}, {'created': '2019-01-11 20:07:19.000000000', 'message': "Fix the subprocess invocation of neutron-l3-agent

neutron-l3-agent tries to invoke neutron-keepalived-state-change
from it's PATH. The venv's bin directory is not part of the
default PATH of the neutron-l3-agent, hence the invocation fails.
This change adds the venv's bin directory to the PATH of
neutron-l3-agent.

To the best of my knowledge this is currently the only script
which is invoked and shipped by neutron itself [1]. Neutron expects
quite a few binaries in it's PATH, however other expected binaries
are typically system packages (e.g. radvd) [2].

Sadly, the PATH can not easily be extended, hence all non venv-bin
directories from the PATH are a 'one-time snapshot' from a quite
common set of directories across all common linux distributions.

[1]
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/search?q=%22cmd+%3D+%27neutron-%22&unscoped_q=%22cmd+%3D+%27neutron-%22
[2]
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/search?q=external_process.ProcessManager&unscoped_q=external_process.ProcessManager

Depends-On: I504a8270be1ddf2f24ab3ad3b4f2f4ca9c990470
Change-Id: I38bb573468dd4c57523cc1a5ff2448009ee2b216
"}]
commit_message:
Fix the subprocess invocation of neutron-l3-agent

neutron-l3-agent tries to invoke neutron-keepalived-state-change
from it's PATH. The venv's bin directory is not part of the
default PATH of the neutron-l3-agent, hence the invocation fails.
This change adds the venv's bin directory to the PATH of
neutron-l3-agent.

To the best of my knowledge this is currently the only script
which is invoked and shipped by neutron itself [1]. Neutron expects
quite a few binaries in it's PATH, however other expected binaries
are typically system packages (e.g. radvd) [2].

Sadly, the PATH can not easily be extended, hence all non venv-bin
directories from the PATH are a 'one-time snapshot' from a quite
common set of directories across all common linux distributions.

[1]
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/search?q=%22cmd+%3D+%27neutron-%22&unscoped_q=%22cmd+%3D+%27neutron-%22
[2]
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/search?q=external_process.ProcessManager&unscoped_q=external_process.ProcessManager

Depends-On: I504a8270be1ddf2f24ab3ad3b4f2f4ca9c990470
Change-Id: I38bb573468dd4c57523cc1a5ff2448009ee2b216

Add upstream pip bug reference

To make it easier to follow up on later, we add a
reference to the upstream bug. This will allow us
to determine whether the bug is fixed in the future,
so that we can remove the workaround.

Change-Id: I7f0e69f3e30bd2ed18c0f340968520792a3c1f46

commit_message:
Add Tempest gate job for stable/stein

Now we have stable/stein branch ready for devstack
and so does for all service projects.

This commit adds the Tempest testing for stable/stein
by adding new jobs running on stable/stein version of
openstack.
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/647867/

Change-Id: Ia22988821b5c786a0b25a980cb4ca329dac54bac

[{'created': '2019-03-22 01:10:13.000000000', 'message': 'Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Idc79a152a4246fdacfc3d0bcabce488825b26e08
'}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Idc79a152a4246fdacfc3d0bcabce488825b26e08

messages:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-24 21:06:19.000000000', 'message': 'Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: I76c76ecc61676380c6225b169ff0e4e79bfb1a67
'}]
commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: I76c76ecc61676380c6225b169ff0e4e79bfb1a67

commit_message:
NetApp: Return all iSCSI targets-portals

NetApp iSCSI drivers use discovery mode for multipathing, which means
that we'll fail to attach a volume if the IP provided for the discovery
is not accessible from the host.

Something similar would happen when using singlepath, as we are only
trying to connect to one target/portal.

This patch changes NetApp drivers so the return target_iqns,
target_portals, and target_luns parameters whenever there are more than
one option.

Closes-Bug: #1806398
Change-Id: If6b5ad23c899032dbf7535ed91251cbfe54a223a

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-01 18:49:40.000000000', 'message': 'Elasticsearch: Add job to wait for Elasticsearch cluster formation

This adds a job that will query the Elasticsearch HTTP cat API to
determine whether the desired number of nodes have been discovered
via the Zen discovery mechanism to be included in the cluster.
This aims to address issues seen when upgrading Elasticsearch,
where the snapshot repository job may trigger due to endpoints
from older pods being present. This new job will be the dependency
required by the snapshot repository job to ensure the ES cluster
has the desired number of nodes before attempting to register a
snapshot repository or interact with the cluster

Change-Id: I94fbbfdec7ca66d04acca9558e56dca3b2bc7d52
'}, {'created': '2019-04-01 18:50:16.000000000', 'message': 'Elasticsearch: Add job to wait for Elasticsearch cluster formation

commit_message:
Elasticsearch: Add job to wait for Elasticsearch cluster formation

This adds a job that will query the Elasticsearch HTTP cat API to
determine whether the desired number of nodes have been discovered
via the Zen discovery mechanism to be included in the cluster.
This aims to address issues seen when upgrading Elasticsearch,
where the snapshot repository job may trigger due to endpoints
from older pods being present. This new job will be the dependency
required by the snapshot repository job to ensure the ES cluster
has the desired number of nodes before attempting to register a
snapshot repository or interact with the cluster

Change-Id: I94fbbfdec7ca66d04acca9558e56dca3b2bc7d52

commit_message:
Add privsep-helper to neutron sudoers file

With the new oslo-privsep library, there is now a
privsep-helper command that is used to escalate
privledges.

This command needs to be runnable by the neutron user
via sudo without a password. The old rootwrap command
is still used as well, so for now we need to have
both.

Change-Id: I8e9743da3e51e71a113d958c22007cf54aa17fc4

commit_message:
Mariadb: Disable wsrep during setting of password

This PS disables wsrep during the setting of admin passwords, which
is required to allow the cluster to come up from a dead stop.

Change-Id: Id9af65d57755f62afc672900bca79e5b11e9c8c9
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: I9398fd4173f40e26acc212be34c4bbca165bb82e

commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: Icdb187ec943713a098032c73a1cda8316424bf3a

commit_message:
Consolidate apparmor check jobs

There was an additional job added for checking libvirt's apparmor
profiles separately from the standard apparmor job that existed
previously. This adds the libvirt deployment to the previously
existing apparmor job and removes the apparmor-libvirt job.

Change-Id: I76b00f1e5dca4236f62150e4ac48b0777a05b29f

commit_message:
[ceph-osd] Fix ceph osd init script to handle udev

This is to fix udev_settle function by adding timeout for blkid
command as it will get stuck  on the host sometimes.

Change-Id: I378748991eecda9ea2af383ea04ecd97ab3d2948

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-25 03:17:57.000000000', 'message': "Fix prefix for vip_ipv6

Currently we calculate prefix based on netmask when writing the vip
interface file. Since netmask has been converted to prefix in ipv6,
this patch will avoid converting it to prefix twice which could
result in a wrong prefix length.

Also fix a bug in another test that relies on osutils, but wasn't
mocking correctly.

Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I9ee0cce12a975f4ab8f3df2707b355aab35c6cb3
(cherry picked from commit b2162c39a2017b12a59d2be745958a5fe3ad6403)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix prefix for vip_ipv6

Currently we calculate prefix based on netmask when writing the vip
interface file. Since netmask has been converted to prefix in ipv6,
this patch will avoid converting it to prefix twice which could
result in a wrong prefix length.

Also fix a bug in another test that relies on osutils, but wasn't
mocking correctly.

Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I9ee0cce12a975f4ab8f3df2707b355aab35c6cb3
(cherry picked from commit b2162c39a2017b12a59d2be745958a5fe3ad6403)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-03 04:35:08.000000000', 'message': 'Automatically prune the inventory backup

The inventory backup process takes the running inventory json file and
adds it to a tar archive. This process has no limits and will add files
to the tar archive until that is no longer possible and limited by the
underlying operating system. This change automatically prunes the backup
file and retains only the last 15 inventory files. This should provide
the same backup capabilities we've had without trying to saving
archives indefinitely.

> It should be noted that this change is using a subprocess call to
  prune the tar file. This is being done because the "tarfile" library
  does not provide an interface for deleting a file within an archive.

Change-Id: Ida5a9be0d0910c223fe05401bc4f75aef100e456
Closes-Bug: #1750233
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-05-03 15:24:27.000000000', 'message': 'Automatically prune the inventory backup

commit_message:
Automatically prune the inventory backup

The inventory backup process takes the running inventory json file and
adds it to a tar archive. This process has no limits and will add files
to the tar archive until that is no longer possible and limited by the
underlying operating system. This change automatically prunes the backup
file and retains only the last 15 inventory files. This should provide
the same backup capabilities we've had without trying to saving
archives indefinitely.

> It should be noted that this change is using a subprocess call to
  prune the tar file. This is being done because the "tarfile" library
  does not provide an interface for deleting a file within an archive.

Change-Id: Ida5a9be0d0910c223fe05401bc4f75aef100e456
Closes-Bug: #1750233
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Create /volumes when using external ceph

Currently we only create the /volumes directory when
using the kolla-ansible bundled ceph. This extends the
functionality to external ceph.

Note: In addition to the cherry-picked commit, we add jmespath to
requirements as it is required for the json_query filter.

Change-Id: I1e9a40e4ee893a53f04909ef7835be005c9b5276
Closes-Bug: #1778720
(cherry picked from commit 2f6b1c6890cf7ea6b0dd33ac219646e4dcaf1fd6)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-06 01:59:34.000000000', 'message': 'Alternative Replace UUID with id_generator for Federated users

Breaks Provider contract

The LDAP code has long had a swappable backend to generate
the user IDs that map from LDAP to SQL.  THe Federated code
was supposed to use the same mechanism, but it ended up
generating a UUID for the userid instead.  This is a backwards
compatible change that converts the Federated UserIDs to a
sha256 hash of the same 3 pieces of data that LDAP now uses:
the domain_id, the unique ID from the Federated backend, and
the entity type (User).

This code is tested via
tox -e py35 -- keystone.tests.unit.test_shadow_users

Longer IDs show up in some of the Federation tests

Change-Id: I260e8a73bfa94c9845a381fd049a566d0e7aca93
closes-bug: 1641639

commit_message:
Alternative Replace UUID with id_generator for Federated users

Breaks Provider contract

The LDAP code has long had a swappable backend to generate
the user IDs that map from LDAP to SQL.  THe Federated code
was supposed to use the same mechanism, but it ended up
generating a UUID for the userid instead.  This is a backwards
compatible change that converts the Federated UserIDs to a
sha256 hash of the same 3 pieces of data that LDAP now uses:
the domain_id, the unique ID from the Federated backend, and
the entity type (User).

This code is tested via
tox -e py35 -- keystone.tests.unit.test_shadow_users

Longer IDs show up in some of the Federation tests

Change-Id: I260e8a73bfa94c9845a381fd049a566d0e7aca93
closes-bug: 1641639

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-28 18:26:03.000000000', 'message': 'Inhibit automatic vbmcd start in devstack

Older versions of VirtualBMC worked without any server keeping
state on the filesystem. The contemporary version is build around
client-server model. To preserve backward compatibility, the
`vbmc` client can invoke `vbmcd` behind the scenes if the daemon
is not running.

This patch inhibits this automatic `vbmcd` start behaviour because
devstack invokes `vbmcd` explicitly through systemd.

Change-Id: I944837915ddf8874865bf8f47b2f2195e5632622
'}]
commit_message:
Inhibit automatic vbmcd start in devstack

Older versions of VirtualBMC worked without any server keeping
state on the filesystem. The contemporary version is build around
client-server model. To preserve backward compatibility, the
`vbmc` client can invoke `vbmcd` behind the scenes if the daemon
is not running.

This patch inhibits this automatic `vbmcd` start behaviour because
devstack invokes `vbmcd` explicitly through systemd.

Change-Id: I944837915ddf8874865bf8f47b2f2195e5632622

commit_message:
Bootstrap the v2 API

This adds a v2 API root to CloudKitty. An example endpoint along with some
developer documentation has been added. The API root is now served with Flask
instead of pecan.

Change-Id: I4ede52dae531631f7fe708400def01bc08a64dec
Story: 2004208
Task: 27717
Task: 27718
Task: 27719

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-20 16:41:23.000000000', 'message': 'Only import libvirt secret when nova is enabled

This fixes a small logical error, we only want to set a libvirt secret
if nova is enabled, not both cinder and nova.  This prevents a
deployment with cinder but not nova from being successful.

Change-Id: Ief83fe661cf1b2099af8131a7a206ffca3458dc7
'}]
commit_message:
Only import libvirt secret when nova is enabled

This fixes a small logical error, we only want to set a libvirt secret
if nova is enabled, not both cinder and nova.  This prevents a
deployment with cinder but not nova from being successful.

Change-Id: Ief83fe661cf1b2099af8131a7a206ffca3458dc7

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-23 14:22:48.000000000', 'message': "Add trait cache for multicreate

The _fill_provider_mapping() calls the placement to get traits of the
RPs in the allocation for each instance during build. In a multi create
request multiple instance might hit the same compute host so caching the
traits of the RPs on those compute host reduces the placement load.

This patch adds such rp-trait caches for multi create.

NOTE: I don't think that today multi-create can be used with port's that
has resource request (those the one that triggers
_fill_provider_mapping) because for multi create to work the user needs
to pass networks to the server create API insted of pre-created Neutron
ports. However ports with resource request only supported if pre-created
ports are passed to the server create API.

Change-Id: I8e8248981b533cb4c37e89009f5839e41d9c6649
"}, {'created': '2019-03-27 17:27:28.000000000', 'message': "Change the TODO to NOTE about instance multi-create

The _fill_provider_mapping() calls the placement to get traits of the
RPs in the allocation for each instance during build. In a multi create
request multiple instance might hit the same compute host so caching the
traits of the RPs on those compute host reduces the placement load.

However multi-create can be used with port's that has resource request
(those the one that triggers _fill_provider_mapping) because for multi
create to work the user needs to pass networks to the server create API
insted of pre-created Neutron ports. However ports with resource request
only supported if pre-created ports are passed to the server create API.

Therefore this patch corrects the TODO about multi-create in
_fill_provider_mapping.

Change-Id: I8e8248981b533cb4c37e89009f5839e41d9c6649
"}]
commit_message:
Change the TODO to NOTE about instance multi-create

The _fill_provider_mapping() calls the placement to get traits of the
RPs in the allocation for each instance during build. In a multi create
request multiple instance might hit the same compute host so caching the
traits of the RPs on those compute host reduces the placement load.

However multi-create can be used with port's that has resource request
(those the one that triggers _fill_provider_mapping) because for multi
create to work the user needs to pass networks to the server create API
insted of pre-created Neutron ports. However ports with resource request
only supported if pre-created ports are passed to the server create API.

Therefore this patch corrects the TODO about multi-create in
_fill_provider_mapping.

Change-Id: I8e8248981b533cb4c37e89009f5839e41d9c6649

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-29 17:10:56.000000000', 'message': 'Lower neutron rpc max response timeout

This configuration option is used to determine the max exponential
retry which can lead to beaker failures because the ovs agent starts at
the same time as neutron server. We need to force a retry sooner than
waiting 600 seconds for it to try again.

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/623401/

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/648735/
Change-Id: I7f66c811aa507e76e1b4e087a4a7df5999f4ee50
'}]
commit_message:
Lower neutron rpc max response timeout

This configuration option is used to determine the max exponential
retry which can lead to beaker failures because the ovs agent starts at
the same time as neutron server. We need to force a retry sooner than
waiting 600 seconds for it to try again.

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/623401/

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/648735/
Change-Id: I7f66c811aa507e76e1b4e087a4a7df5999f4ee50

through from pbr.

commit_message:
Implement system reader functionality for grants

This commit opens up the assignment API for system readers and system
members to list and check grants for users and groups on projects and
domains. Subsequent patches will:

 - refactor system admin policy checks
 - implement domain reader and member support
 - implement domain admin support
 - introduce test coverage for project users and the grants API
 - remove redundant policies from policy.v3cloudsample.json

Change-Id: I04bafe2f7c83addddf18591eaeba80277321139b
Related-Bug: 1805368
Related-Bug: 1750669
Related-Bug: 1806762
(cherry picked from commit d1cfa3ab3f87f15f61c5387670d3b75ee2ba93ba)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-25 19:48:30.000000000', 'message': "Consolidate user protection tests

This commit removes user policies from policy.v3cloudsample.json. By
incorporating system-scope, domain-scope, project-scope, and default
roles, we've effectively made these policies obsolete. We can simplify
what we maintain and provide a more consistent, unified view of
default user behavior by removing them.

This commit also adds an important filter to the GET /v3/users API by
making sure the users in the response are filtered properly if the API
was called with a domain-scoped token. This is needed in case domain
configuration isn't setup and short-circuits normalization of the
domain ID, which sometimes comes from the token if it is
domain-scoped.  Regardless of domain configuration being used, we
should protect against cases where data leaks across domains in the
name of security.

Finally, this commit moves a couple of tests from test_v3_protection
to test_users protection tests that ensures we do reasonable filtering
while normalizing domain IDs. The remaining tests from
test_v3_protection have been removed because they are no longer
applicable. These tests were testing an HTTP 403 was returned when a
domain users attempted to filter users for domains they didn't have
authorization on. We don't use this approach consistently in keystone.
Most other places where filtering is implemented, we ignore invalid
filters and instead return an empty list. For domain users attempting
to fish information out of another domain, they will receive an empty
list to be consistent with other parts of the API.

Change-Id: I60b2e2b8af172c369eab0eb2c29f056f5c98ad16
Parial-Bug: 1806762
(cherry picked from commit 9a715beb17780eb34ab64ba9c636f16b34cf1b48)

commit_message:
Consolidate user protection tests

This commit removes user policies from policy.v3cloudsample.json. By
incorporating system-scope, domain-scope, project-scope, and default
roles, we've effectively made these policies obsolete. We can simplify
what we maintain and provide a more consistent, unified view of
default user behavior by removing them.

This commit also adds an important filter to the GET /v3/users API by
making sure the users in the response are filtered properly if the API
was called with a domain-scoped token. This is needed in case domain
configuration isn't setup and short-circuits normalization of the
domain ID, which sometimes comes from the token if it is
domain-scoped.  Regardless of domain configuration being used, we
should protect against cases where data leaks across domains in the
name of security.

Finally, this commit moves a couple of tests from test_v3_protection
to test_users protection tests that ensures we do reasonable filtering
while normalizing domain IDs. The remaining tests from
test_v3_protection have been removed because they are no longer
applicable. These tests were testing an HTTP 403 was returned when a
domain users attempted to filter users for domains they didn't have
authorization on. We don't use this approach consistently in keystone.
Most other places where filtering is implemented, we ignore invalid
filters and instead return an empty list. For domain users attempting
to fish information out of another domain, they will receive an empty
list to be consistent with other parts of the API.

Change-Id: I60b2e2b8af172c369eab0eb2c29f056f5c98ad16
Parial-Bug: 1806762
(cherry picked from commit d2cc4c83c00256440eed0ed5b8d7131cc02d72d4)

commit_message:
Add spice-native type

The remote-consoles API is modified to accept a new spice-native type.
The api will return a collection of feilds which are needed for the native
client to connect to the proxy. Such as "proxy", "host" and "port".
"proxy" feild is the network address of the nova-spicehtml5proxy service.
"host" is the authentication token as it is currenly used for console
client authentication.

Partially implements blueprint spice-native-client-support
Co-authored-by: Artom Lifshitz <alifshit@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id6ff6373661943057f606b5ff8e11523018a6053

subject: Support HTTP CONNECT in websocket proxy

commit_message:
Support HTTP CONNECT in websocket proxy

Websocket proxy will handle HTTP CONNECT to support native clients
that doesn't communicate via websockets.

Partially implements blueprint spice-native-client-support
Co-authored-by: Artom Lifshitz <alifshit@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I8fc70f435d5eb1a4bd8043ad8f72821763f0700b

...while I wait on mdbooth's further input"}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-01-26 14:07:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The problem here is the 'meaning' of destroy_disks, which is kinda a head-screwy quantum superposition of (destroy_disks|destroy_instance_files). It is set differently in different contexts, and used variously in both contexts. This is obviously impossible, which is why this fails in edge cases.

In revert_resize, on the destination we want to:

1. Delete the instance directory unconditionally (shared or not, because the backup copy has been renamed).
2. Delete non-shared block devices.

When using Ceph for block we're probably (although not necessarily) not using NFS for instance directories. In revert_resize we do:

  destroy_disks = not self._is_instance_storage_shared(
      context, instance, host=migration.source_compute)

This is going to return True for Ceph even though we're not using a shared instance directory.

        shared_storage = True   <- defaults to true
        data = None
        try:
            data = self.driver.check_instance_shared_storage_local(context,
                                                       instance)
            ^^^ hardcoded by libvirt driver to return None for Ceph

            if data:
                shared_storage = (self.compute_rpcapi.
                                  check_instance_shared_storage(context,
                                  instance, data, host=host))
                ^^^ therefore not executed
        ...
        return shared_storage
        ^^^ therefore True

So destroy_disks on Ceph is False here.

And when we get to driver.cleanup(destroy_disks), we do:

  if destroy_disks:
    cleanup lvm/rbd

  if destroy_disks (or blah blah blah):
    cleanup instance dir

Neither of which happen, because we gave it False.

To fix the immediate issue, destroy_disks should be False, then True here. IOW we need 2 variables.

<s>Either that or we have compute manager pass in an object with a __nonzero__ method frigged to return the correct sequence of values. Perhaps it could use introspection on the parent stack frame to determine the context it's being evaluated in.</s>

Really, though, compute manager shouldn't be concerning itself with shared storage. Compute manager should simply indicate the caller intent, and leave the rest to the driver. destroy_disks here is incredibly confusing.

As this change is simpler than changing RPC I'm going to have another look at whether it breaks any other edge cases I can think of. If not then we might be able to go with it if accompanied by a sufficiently huge code comment."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-01-26 14:25:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10224, 'date': '2017-01-26 22:09:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

@Matthew, i tried to add an additional parameter in [1] and use it in [2]. This did not require RPC interface changing. However that solution was more complex. And the final reason why i decided to refuse it was that hypothetically that set of parameter allows destroy_disks=True and delete_files=False, which is nonsense. Because both cleanup and destroy methods are called only if we want to remove the instance directory. As the result we might get an ability to use these methods for partially cleaning of instance resources except file directory. I dislike that semantic extension of the methods, especially made by bug fixing.

Please, write here your decision about this approach. If you agree with this, i'll address your comments for tests.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/385492
[2] https://review.openstack.org/385493"}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-01-27 11:10:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Feodor,

Please excuse me for having been a bit vague. This is genuinely because I don't know my own mind. All I know for certain is that I see a proposed 6 line change, I've spent more than half a day total so far trying to decide if it's correct or not, and I still haven't convinced myself either way. This is extreme code smell. I've complained before about the guards sprinkled around the driver of the type 'if phase of moon and is_sacrificed(goat)' which just happen to correspond closely enough in effect to the desired behaviour in enough cases to be functional, but due to their inscrutability are almost impossible to change, with the consequence that everything related is also impossible to change. This is one of those, and I'm trying to decide whether or not it's worth a rebellion. I do realise this is just what we have to work with.

Thanks for pointing out your previous patches. I also appreciate that as this is your second attempt, nobody has more context on it than you, and you've likely already considered everything I can think of.

It occurred to me that it's strange that ComputeManager should concern itself directly in the logic of whether and how the driver is using shared storage. My current thinking is that this is the real source of the problem. destroy_disks is unfathomable because it lost its meaning long ago when driver behaviour changed, and it has never been updated. I think the ComputeManager should communicate *intent* to the driver, which should then be entirely responsible for the implementation. In this case, the intent is: destroy *a copy* of the instance.

So lets say we change the destroy signature to destroy(is_copy=False). is_copy would be set unconditionally to true when called from _destroy_evacuated_instances, revert_resize, and the various live migration calls. ComputeManager would never inspect for shared storage.

Then in the driver we know that if we're not destroying just a copy we can just go ahead and blow everything away. If we are destroying a copy, we need to be careful not to delete anything on shared storage. The driver can then check for shared instance directory[1] and shared block storage separately, and act appropriately.

Incidentally, I also hate the word 'copy' above, but couldn't think of anything better. It's half of a migration.

Anyway, by having ComputeManager directly communicating its intent, the driver doesn't then have to second guess what the hell it's supposed be doing by examining the phase of the moon.

Naively, this doesn't even sound hard to implement to me, and it would make it so much easier to see whether or not the edge cases are covered. What do you think?

Matt

P.S. revert_resize is a curious case, because we do actually want to unconditionally delete the instance directory whether it's on shared storage or not (because it has been renamed), but not shared block. We don't currently do this, but it works anyway due to a workaround in LibvirtDriver.finish_revert_migration(), which first deletes the copy, then renames the backup of the original. I guess the driver has this context too, though, because it knows whether the instance is currently resized.

[1] And cache the result per destination compute?"}, {'account_id': 10224, 'date': '2017-01-27 18:36:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Matthew, your comment was clean enough, it's my fault, i was a bit innatentive at 1 p.m. Anyway i understand that it took much your time to dig into this problem, and i'm impressed that you spent the half of a day only.

I thought about 'intent' idea, but found it brings questions not enough easy for bug fixing. Although potentially it's much better. Moreover hyperv driver handles the shared storage case for cold migration by itself own, not loading manager for this.

The questions are:

1 IIANM there is no way to figure out from inside libvirt driver if instance directory is shared. manager calls another host for that, but driver cannot do it.

2 Other parameters of destroy and cleanup methods work like flags to destroy or not to destroy something. And they are used for that (in _post_live_migration at least). From some side it perhaps makes sense to have similar interface for all instance parts. I.e. to handle destroying of any instance parts from manager. Otherwise it brings a question: why would not get rid of these flags, moving decisions about what to destroy into driver layer.

3 If we change semantic of the methods, we firstly need to figure out, what is that they intended for? If it's needed to cleanup host out of instance (completely or leaving shared parts), why live migration methods do not call them in shared filesystem case? This is not consistent.

Probably there were another questions, but since i found them monthes ago, these are all what i remember now."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-01-30 10:13:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm convinced that the principal of 'intent' is the way to go here. That is, ComputeManager should clearly communicate what it wants to achieve to the driver, which should then implement it. ComputeManager should not second guess the implementation of the driver (for example, by testing for shared storage). I'm also convinced that destroy_disks no longer does this. This is without prejudice to the original author: I suspect it was fine when it was first written, but it was not refactored when it should have been and no longer makes sense.

I'm not necessarily convinced that my 'copy' suggestion is the correct implementation of that intent. You've spent far longer thinking about this than I have. Can you think of anything more thorough?

As for you questions:

1. Hmm, yes. I knew there was an RPC call involved, but it hadn't occurred to me the driver couldn't just make it. Why is that, btw?

2. Yes, I don't think ComputeManager should know anything about these things. Doesn't mean we'd have to do it all at once, though.

3. Completely agree. However, the fact that we don't fully know what they're for is (I believe) the root of the current problem. I think we need to solve that either way.

Anyway, I'd be happy to have a real time chat about this, IRC or video conf. Once we can convince ourselves we fully understand the problem I think the solution will be relatively simple and self-contained. This is not an imagebackend scale problem!"}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-01-31 16:25:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

For some additional context, this came up today, which fixes a severe bug: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/427267/ . I'm still reviewing that patch, but at first glance it looks sensible and obviously correct. However, it adds a new user of destroy_disks, and if we had taken this patch likely nobody would have noticed that it didn't fix Rbd disks."}, {'account_id': 10224, 'date': '2017-01-31 17:19:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Matthew,

i agree that 'intent' approach is attractive, and the fact that manager has to know custom implementation details of some driver is weird and disgusting. I agree that initially destroy_disks flag was probably appropriate, but now its initial using has gone.

The only thought i mean here is that reworking of this looks more than work on regular bug fixing. It requires more thinking about various cases, including impact for other drivers, since in this case we want to get consistent code in both manager and driver levels. Unlike that reworking, this patch does not change the interaction model.

I'm not against the reworking, but right now i'm not sure i'll have resources for this in the near future. (if someone would tell with me 3 monthes ago...)

1 The driver might make the call. But now it never calls other hosts, even indirectly, right? We have RPC API over manager API. But we do not have RPC API over driver (or even libvirt driver) API. If we call manager API on another host from driver, it looks weird. If we call driver own manager for that, it looks a little better. I do not see a good simple solution for that at the first glance.

2,3 You're right. These questions (and the 1st as well) are resolvable. But these are additional questions need to be resolved. Additional for the goal of this patch - to fix a custom case. And again - i'm not against a full straightforward consistent solution, but such changes takes a lot of time at review stage (potentially resulted with 'we do not want to have this' resolution, hehe), and currently i do not know if i have resources for Nova for the future.

As for chatting about this - i'll try to find time to ping you in IRC on the week."}, {'account_id': 10224, 'date': '2017-01-31 18:28:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> and if we had taken this patch likely nobody would have noticed
 > that it didn't fix Rbd disks.

You mean that destroy_disks is going to get back its initial meaning? So the first premiss in the commit message ('cleanup is only invoked if a logic wants do delete instance files') is becoming wrong?"}, {'account_id': 10224, 'date': '2017-04-26 10:50:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

well, this should be rethought'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-04-01 16:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

[{'created': '2016-10-21 08:26:57.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Fix deletion of instance files in migration cases

TBD

Closes-Bug: 1631481

'}, {'created': '2016-10-24 11:37:19.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Fix deletion of instance files in migration cases

Currently cleanup method requires specified migrate_data to delete
instance file keeping instance disks. It is required in shared block
storage case. But migrate_data is an object that exists in live
migration case only. Because that other cases (like resizing) cannot
delete the files properly.

This fix changes the logic to delete the files not depending on
migrate_data. The work is based on conclusions:
- driver.cleanup is only invoked (explicitly or via destroy or
rollback_live_migration_at_destination) if a logic wants to delete
instance files. If it wants to keep them, it does not call cleanup (e.g.
see how _post_live_migration works if instance path is shared).
- Other host resources related to the instance (volume mappings, vifs,
etc) are cleaned if corresponding arguments are passed.
- Therefore driver.cleanup must always delete the files if it does not
conflict with passed arguments.
- The only argument may affect on the file deletion is
destroy_disks=False which is used to keep shared disks in various
migration cases. If the disks are file based and stored in the instance
path, cleanup method cannot delete the instance files.
- Active host image backend reports if disks are stored in instance
path, and this may be used to decide whether to delete instance files in
cleanup method.

An alternative might be to delete instance files if block storage is
shared only and destroy_disks is False, but this would be not so clear.

Closes-Bug: 1631481
Change-Id: I8d65c9045be67556ccea8464e36adc4af22f1cb8
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Fix deletion of instance files in migration cases

Currently cleanup method requires specified migrate_data to delete
instance file keeping instance disks. It is required in shared block
storage case. But migrate_data is an object that exists in live
migration case only. Because that other cases (like resizing) cannot
delete the files properly.

This fix changes the logic to delete the files not depending on
migrate_data. The work is based on conclusions:
- driver.cleanup is only invoked (explicitly or via destroy or
rollback_live_migration_at_destination) if a logic wants to delete
instance files. If it wants to keep them, it does not call cleanup (e.g.
see how _post_live_migration works if instance path is shared).
- Other host resources related to the instance (volume mappings, vifs,
etc) are cleaned if corresponding arguments are passed.
- Therefore driver.cleanup must always delete the files if it does not
conflict with passed arguments.
- The only argument may affect on the file deletion is
destroy_disks=False which is used to keep shared disks in various
migration cases. If the disks are file based and stored in the instance
path, cleanup method cannot delete the instance files.
- Active host image backend reports if disks are stored in instance
path, and this may be used to decide whether to delete instance files in
cleanup method.

An alternative might be to delete instance files if block storage is
shared only and destroy_disks is False, but this would be not so clear.

Closes-Bug: 1631481
Change-Id: I8d65c9045be67556ccea8464e36adc4af22f1cb8

commit_message:
Add debug logs to output host weights for weighers

The weighers, however, only give the combined weight after all
filters have been applied. This change allows to see the weight each
weigher contributes in the debug log so that we can troubleshoot
scheduler problems better.

Change-Id: Ia971c697078315802bea800a32ca46ad980099be
Closes-Bug: #1446716

-connection information for a console- code
(nova/compute/manager.py)

In general, removing code duplication is a good idea. However, in this way, you just simply merged two duplicated methods into one, and duplication is still there, but in one method. commit_message:
Remove code-duplication from utils

Remove the Extended notify_about_instance_action related
code duplication and transform the new calls to the old with
extra_usage_info parameters.

Change-Id: I40e986ced9378286631ad2e5cdb41028cd66ffff

TBH I don't like this approach for reducing the code complexity in this case.  It seems to be aimed at reducing an arbitrary measure (presumably function length) by making the code harder to follow.

I'd suggest a different approach - perhaps a series of helper methods which all take task states?  e.g. 778-805 could be _maybe_set_error_state, 807-829 could be _maybe_clear_task_state and so on.
The conditional logic for each of the operations would then be in the helper methods, rather than the main function."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-07-20 02:11:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Verified-1

Reduce code complexity - manager.py

Reduce the code complexity in
nova/compute/manager.py file.

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 18603, 'date': '2017-06-14 05:17:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 18603, 'date': '2017-06-14 05:20:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Out of curiosity, what did you use to calculate the cyclomatic
 > complexity?

Hi!
The McCabe’s cyclomatic complexity (McCC) is used
McCC: "complexity of the method/function expressed as the number of independent control flow paths in it. It represents a lower bound for the number of possible execution paths in the source code and at the same time it is an upper bound for the minimum number of test cases needed for achieving full branch test coverage. The value of the metric is calculated as the number of the following instructions plus 1: if, for, while, except and conditional expression. Moreover, logical “and” and logical “or” expressions also add 1 to the value because their short-circuit evaluation can cause branching depending on the first operand. The following instructions are not included: else, try, finally."'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-06-14 07:00:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

commit_message:
Reduced the complexity of the _init_instance method (2)

The _init_instance method (in nova/compute/manager.py) is very large
- almost 280 lines, and McCabe's cyclomatic complexity 43.
Results: http://openqa.sed.hu/dashboard

I extracted some of the functionalities into helper functions
to reduce the length and complexity of _init_instance.
Additionally it became more readable as well, without
changing its functionality.

Change-Id: Iecd6fec207e1fce220df3f2cf63030a07bdddcc4

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-09-22 09:51:29.000000000', 'message': "Reduced the complexity of the _init_instance method

The _init_instance method (in nova/compute/manager.py) is very large
- almost 280 lines, and McCabe's cyclomatic complexity 43.
http://10.6.13.31:9000/dashboard/index/26163?display_title=true&metric=McCC&sm_resource=29302
I extracted some of the functionalities into helper functions
to reduce the length and complexity of send_cmd.
Additionally it became more readable as well, without
changing its functionality.

Change-Id: I4ed82c04c2ccffb7c41c35acec6616dde75eef29
"}, {'created': '2016-09-23 12:19:37.000000000', 'message': "Reduced the complexity of the _init_instance method

Change-Id: I4ed82c04c2ccffb7c41c35acec6616dde75eef29
"}, {'created': '2016-10-28 07:31:00.000000000', 'message': "Reduced the complexity of the _init_instance method

The _init_instance method (in nova/compute/manager.py) is very large
- almost 280 lines, and McCabe's cyclomatic complexity 43.
http://openqa.sed.hu/dashboard/index/26163?display_title=true&metric=McCC&sm_resource=29302

I extracted some of the functionalities (vm_deleted_failed,
instance_spawn_and_rebuild_failed, not_error_vm_state_action,
task_state_is_deleting, try_reboot_action, task_powering_action_failed,
migrating_task_state_action, instance_rebooting) into helper functions
to reduce the length and complexity of _init_instance.

Additionally it became more readable as well, without
changing its functionality.

commit_message:
Reduced the complexity of the _init_instance method (1)

The _init_instance method (in nova/compute/manager.py) is very large
- almost 280 lines, and McCabe's cyclomatic complexity 43.
Results: http://openqa.sed.hu/dashboard

I extracted some of the functionalities into helper functions
to reduce the length and complexity of _init_instance.
Additionally it became more readable as well, without
changing its functionality.

Change-Id: I4ed82c04c2ccffb7c41c35acec6616dde75eef29

commit_message:
Branching stable/stein upstream jobs

The only required change for stein branching upstream is

* scenario012-standalone is unstable (will run on master only)

While duplicating master jobs to stable/stein branch, most of jobs
don't require any changes as they do not exclude stable/stein
in branches regex. So this is basically a no-op change.

* scenario00{1-4}-multinode-oooq-container were translated to
  standalone and should no longer run on master and stein.

* fedora-28-standalone will run stein and master

* build-containers-centos-7-buildah (will run on master and stein)

Change-Id: I4732c1474b6a3d4e9a94177c0f332ff5807c7dfa
Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/us/864

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-19 19:11:10.000000000', 'message': 'Ease python 3 classifier check in check_python3_support_for_package_local

This makes the grep match in check_python3_support_for_package_local
the same as check_python3_support_for_package_remote.

Change I0349de2026c49279ba7f262d5e86d37018d66326 in grenade started
setting the PYTHON3_VERSION variable, and then we recently started
using bionic nodes everywhere which means we're running python 3.6.

The etcd3gw package has a python 3 and 3.5 classifier, but not 3.6:

https://pypi.org/project/etcd3gw/

The pip_install function code that is dealing with installing py3
packages is hitting a problem installing etcd3gw if the package is
local because of the more restrictive grep in the
check_python3_support_for_package_local function, and since
PYTHON3_VERSION=3.6 now, we don't install from py3 and install
etcd3gw on python 2.7 which makes services like cinder-volume and
cinder-backup, which use etcd3gw, fail when they are running under
python 3 (they get module import errors).

This simply removes the $ restriction on the grep. Looking at the
change that added those local/remote functions:

  I243ea4b76f0d5ef57a03b5b0798a05468ee6de9b

There is no explanation for the difference, it just said:

  Also, since not many packages are classified correctly, fallback
  to looking for just "Programming Language :: Python :: 3" and
  log a message for the package to highlight the problem.

So that's what this change does.

Note that alternatives would be:

1. Update the etcd3gw package to add the 3.6 classifier and do
   a release (this should probably happen anyway).

2. Add etcd3gw to ENABLED_PYTHON3_PACKAGES but that would be a
   short-term hack workaround.

Change-Id: Icd3768870ba0f1659bb2e6f002043d975047b73e
Closes-Bug: #1820892
'}]
commit_message:
Ease python 3 classifier check in check_python3_support_for_package_local

This makes the grep match in check_python3_support_for_package_local
the same as check_python3_support_for_package_remote.

Change I0349de2026c49279ba7f262d5e86d37018d66326 in grenade started
setting the PYTHON3_VERSION variable, and then we recently started
using bionic nodes everywhere which means we're running python 3.6.

The etcd3gw package has a python 3 and 3.5 classifier, but not 3.6:

https://pypi.org/project/etcd3gw/

The pip_install function code that is dealing with installing py3
packages is hitting a problem installing etcd3gw if the package is
local because of the more restrictive grep in the
check_python3_support_for_package_local function, and since
PYTHON3_VERSION=3.6 now, we don't install from py3 and install
etcd3gw on python 2.7 which makes services like cinder-volume and
cinder-backup, which use etcd3gw, fail when they are running under
python 3 (they get module import errors).

This simply removes the $ restriction on the grep. Looking at the
change that added those local/remote functions:

  I243ea4b76f0d5ef57a03b5b0798a05468ee6de9b

There is no explanation for the difference, it just said:

  Also, since not many packages are classified correctly, fallback
  to looking for just "Programming Language :: Python :: 3" and
  log a message for the package to highlight the problem.

So that's what this change does.

Note that alternatives would be:

1. Update the etcd3gw package to add the 3.6 classifier and do
   a release (this should probably happen anyway).

2. Add etcd3gw to ENABLED_PYTHON3_PACKAGES but that would be a
   short-term hack workaround.

Change-Id: Icd3768870ba0f1659bb2e6f002043d975047b73e
Closes-Bug: #1820892

commit_message:
Reproduce bug #1819460 in functional test

There are two calls during ConductorTaskManager.build_instances,
used during re-schedule, that could potentially raise exceptions
which leads to that the instance is stuck in BUILD state instead
of going to ERROR state.

This patch adds two functional testcase to reproduce the problems.

Change-Id: If80c4e4776b81cc06293989ee41d39b53735352b
Related-Bug: #1819460

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

Change-Id: I4a595d56db7df7ad5da32ab4d676bc3f97728195
'}]
commit_message:
Replace openstack.org git:// URLs with https://

This is a mechanically generated change to replace openstack.org
git:// URLs with https:// equivalents.

This is in aid of a planned future move of the git hosting
infrastructure to a self-hosted instance of gitea (https://gitea.io),
which does not support the git wire protocol at this stage.

This update should result in no functional change.

For more information see the thread at

 http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003825.html

Change-Id: I4a595d56db7df7ad5da32ab4d676bc3f97728195

commit_message:
Add release prelude about changing policies

This change adds a prelude to the release notes to inform operators
about the changing policy defaults and how to handle them, since these
are going to be quite a big change and cause a lot of log warnings.

Change-Id: If067866daa8abbe41027018c260a3e01bddbb92f
Related-bug: #968696
(cherry picked from commit 60e0f00326ee41968730f9d72fc77cab26af3d9f)

subject: Delete shadow users when domain is deleted
messages: [{'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-03-30 14:27:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-03-31 12:50:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2019-04-01 11:06:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-04-01 13:30:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-04-01 14:26:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-30 14:27:57.000000000', 'message': 'Delete shadow users when domain is deleted

Without this change, when an admin tries to delete an LDAP-backed
domain, it fails due to the foreign key relationship in the users table.
Previously, we were assuming that LDAP users existed solely in the LDAP
directory, but this is not true with shadow users. This patch fixes the
logic to delete the shadow users upon domain deletion.

Change-Id: I12a08001e3aa08e4db9438cae425ad1a0a8070f7
Closes-bug: #1801873
(cherry picked from commit 1b16725d066f71a833ca74656c0c3dfe5f815e98)
'}]
commit_message:
Delete shadow users when domain is deleted

Without this change, when an admin tries to delete an LDAP-backed
domain, it fails due to the foreign key relationship in the users table.
Previously, we were assuming that LDAP users existed solely in the LDAP
directory, but this is not true with shadow users. This patch fixes the
logic to delete the shadow users upon domain deletion.

Change-Id: I12a08001e3aa08e4db9438cae425ad1a0a8070f7
Closes-bug: #1801873
(cherry picked from commit 1b16725d066f71a833ca74656c0c3dfe5f815e98)

messages: [{'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-03-25 17:41:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-03-25 17:44:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2019-03-25 17:44:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-03-25 18:17:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nLooks like something good to backport.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2019-03-27 04:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-04-01 14:26:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-25 17:41:45.000000000', 'message': "Only validate tokens once per request

Keystone actually validates each token twice for every API request.
Regardless of caching being configured, we have an opportunity to try
and spend less time doing something we've already done.

The first the token is validated is actually done through a
keystonemiddleware hook. The second time is to populate a context
object that we can use for things like policy decisions.

Closes-Bug: 1819036
Change-Id: Ifd7f6f0a1dcd33ad17646cae383132cfc2462f03
(cherry picked from commit 112fa29a7472d8d51f2bc920fc3a13fea8d6e8b8)
"}]
commit_message:
Only validate tokens once per request

Keystone actually validates each token twice for every API request.
Regardless of caching being configured, we have an opportunity to try
and spend less time doing something we've already done.

The first the token is validated is actually done through a
keystonemiddleware hook. The second time is to populate a context
object that we can use for things like policy decisions.

Closes-Bug: 1819036
Change-Id: Ifd7f6f0a1dcd33ad17646cae383132cfc2462f03
(cherry picked from commit 112fa29a7472d8d51f2bc920fc3a13fea8d6e8b8)

commit_message:
Add git_branch variable

This can be used to change the branch used for all projects in one
place.

It is still necessary to set ipa_upstream_release to change the release
of IPA images.

Change-Id: Ic28958e46783086e89b04e405518504a49725155

commit_message:
Fix pool protocol and algorithm validation

This patch fixes an issue where pool update would raise
UnsupportedOptionError for pool updates with protocol not altered.

It also adds validation for supported algorithms on pool create and
update.

Closes-Bug: #1822277

Change-Id: Ia957018dcb00486124db151ba30cf20505fb1656

commit_message:
Remove non-voting job from the gate pipeline

The tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario007-multinode-oooq-container is marked
as non-voting as per commit 2d2c7ee2c9b7b4b25142d0210924362686a04eb4. We
should not run non-voting jobs in the gate pipeline to save resources
and time.

Change-Id: Ie793b2e1dcdef8847a614216035d055139ce9c24
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-01 01:24:48.000000000', 'message': 'Add privsep-helper to nova sudoers file

With the new oslo-privsep library, there is now a
privsep-helper command that is used to escalate
privledges.

This command needs to be runnable by the nova user
via sudo without a password. The old rootwrap command
is still used as well, so for now we need to have
both.

Change-Id: I3bf334bf9498f67a1e91041d1d50870964e6141c
'}]
commit_message:
Add privsep-helper to nova sudoers file

With the new oslo-privsep library, there is now a
privsep-helper command that is used to escalate
privledges.

This command needs to be runnable by the nova user
via sudo without a password. The old rootwrap command
is still used as well, so for now we need to have
both.

Change-Id: I3bf334bf9498f67a1e91041d1d50870964e6141c

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-01 00:52:24.000000000', 'message': "Eliminate nova_novnc_distro_packages

The variable is useless and it only breaks things.  The js-jquery
packages don't even exist on RedHat.  All those dependencies are
pulled in and vendored in anyways, the Python ones are built, so
noVNC can run with no problem without any of those.

Change-Id: I59ad2014ed001a318ae4b865f0e218b6f8e18d92
"}]
commit_message:
Eliminate nova_novnc_distro_packages

The variable is useless and it only breaks things.  The js-jquery
packages don't even exist on RedHat.  All those dependencies are
pulled in and vendored in anyways, the Python ones are built, so
noVNC can run with no problem without any of those.

Change-Id: I59ad2014ed001a318ae4b865f0e218b6f8e18d92

commit_message:
Remove project policies from policy.v3cloudsample.json

By incorporating system-scope, domain-scope, project-scope, and
default roles, we've effectively made these policies obsolete. We can
simplify what we maintain and provide a more consistent, unified view
of default project behavior by removing them.

Change-Id: I80221b72ce0f234440e6d6aaea51869bd5f1c6e7
Related-Bug: 1806762
(cherry picked from commit 546b7f1bba0c5a9b9c22828cc27a90191bb8f30d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-26 17:22:36.000000000', 'message': '[Stable Only] hardware: Handle races during pinning

Due to how we do claiming of pinned CPUs and related NUMA "things", it's
possible for claims to race. This raciness is usually not an issue since
pinning with fail for the losing instance, which will just get
rescheduled. This does mean that it's possible for an instance to land
on a host with no CPUs at all though and this edge case is triggering a
nasty bug made possible by Python's unusual scoping rules around for
loops.

    >>> for x in range(5):
    ...     pass
    ...
    >>> print(x)
    4

'x' would be considered out of scope in the above for most other
languages (JS and its even dumber scoping rules aside, I guess) and it
leaves us with situations where the variable might never exist, i.e. the
bug at hand:

    >>> for x in range(0):
    ...     pass
    ...
    >>> print(x)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
    NameError: name 'x' is not defined

Resolve this by adding a check to handle the "no CPUs at all" case and
quick fail but also remove the reliance on this quirk of Python.

Change-Id: I6afc3af9f13e3c1cc312112eb28eb6e10d2a9e07
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1821733
'}, {'created': '2019-03-27 12:30:44.000000000', 'message': '[Stable Only] hardware: Handle races during pinning

possible for claims to race. This raciness is usually not an issue since
pinning with fail for the losing instance, which will just get
rescheduled. This does mean that it's possible for an instance to land
on a host with no CPUs at all though and this edge case is triggering a
nasty bug made possible by Python's unusual scoping rules around for
loops.

    >>> x = 5
    >>> for y in range(x):
    ...     pass
    ...
    >>> print(y)
    4

'y' would be considered out of scope in the above for most other
languages (JS and its even dumber scoping rules aside, I guess) and it
leaves us with situations where the variable might never exist, i.e. the
bug at hand:

    >>> x = 0
    >>> for y in range(x):
    ...     pass
    ...
    >>> print(y)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
    NameError: name 'y' is not defined

Resolve this by adding a check to handle the "no CPUs at all" case and
quick fail but also remove the reliance on this quirk of Python.

This doesn't apply to stable/rocky since the issue was inadvertently

I021ce59048d6292055af49457ba642022f648c81. However, those changes are

Change-Id: I6afc3af9f13e3c1cc312112eb28eb6e10d2a9e07

Closes-Bug: #1821733

commit_message:
[Stable Only] hardware: Handle races during pinning

Due to how we do claiming of pinned CPUs and related NUMA "things", it's
possible for claims to race. This raciness is usually not an issue since
pinning with fail for the losing instance, which will just get
rescheduled. This does mean that it's possible for an instance to land
on a host with no CPUs at all though and this edge case is triggering a
nasty bug made possible by Python's unusual scoping rules around for
loops.

    >>> x = 5
    >>> for y in range(x):
    ...     pass
    ...
    >>> print(y)
    4

'y' would be considered out of scope in the above for most other
languages (JS and its even dumber scoping rules aside, I guess) and it
leaves us with situations where the variable might never exist, i.e. the
bug at hand:

    >>> x = 0
    >>> for y in range(x):
    ...     pass
    ...
    >>> print(y)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
    NameError: name 'y' is not defined

Resolve this by adding a check to handle the "no CPUs at all" case and
quick fail but also remove the reliance on this quirk of Python.

This doesn't apply to stable/rocky since the issue was inadvertently
resolved by changes I8982ab25338969cd98621f79b7fbec8af43d12c5 and
I021ce59048d6292055af49457ba642022f648c81. However, those changes are
significantly larger and backports have been previously rejected [1][2].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/588570/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/588571/

Change-Id: I6afc3af9f13e3c1cc312112eb28eb6e10d2a9e07
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1821733

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Icd4ccdf6623c842f95b052c5eda0d497ae10226d

commit_message:
[OVS] Exception message when retrieving bridge-id and is not present

In the OVS agent, when setting up the ancillary bridges, the parameter
external_id:bridge-id is retrieved. If this parameter is not defined
(e.g.: manually created bridges), ovsdbapp writes an error in the logs.
This information is irrelevant and can cause confusion during debugging time.

Change-Id: Ic85db65f651eb67fcb56b937ebe5850ec1e8f29f
Closes-Bug: #1815912

commit_message:
Unroll the ping list

The Python code defining the ping list has gotten a bit messy as
names are added or removed. Instead of trying to keep the formatting
updated, which is a waste of time since we reformat it on output
anyway, just make it a single vertical list that can be easily added
to or removed from.

Change-Id: I636944deb39b682abd29d741bfb9dff41dfb9bee

commit_message:
Set lower addr to avoid IP out of range

Since port creating can result an IP address in the
entire CIDR especially small subnet. And those next
N IP actions can be out of subnet IP range. This
patch gives the original test port a specific IP
addr to prevent this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1812404
Change-Id: I34cb99a518d4469c7d1ca9e2897671608b2b81ad

commit_message:
Improve virt-resize UX

Display errors instead of only redirecting them to the specific
log file in order to avoid extra steps when something fails.

Avoids increase of console output for successful execution of that task.

Change-Id: I28a0b00c22f6732a860b4ebb01d1befcb7647038
Partial-Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1787912
